name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-1
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Glenn E. Bean⁎ , David B. Witkin, Tait D. McLouth, Dhruv N. Patel, Rafael J. Zaldivar

The Aerospace Corporation, 2310 E El Segundo Blvd, El Segundo, CA, 90245, United State

# A R T I C L E I N F O


# A B S T R A C T
Keywords:   
Selective laser melting   
Nickel superalloys   
Porosity   
Surface roughness

Selective laser melting (SLM) is a method of laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing (AM) currently being pursued in numerous industries, including space launch and space flight. In this study we performed an extensive parameter development investigation to better understand the effect of laser parameters on surface roughness, density, and porosity of SLM Inconel 718 parts. Laser energy density was varied via laser focus shift, and the effects on porosity in both as-printed and post-HIP treated states were analyzed. Tensile testing was also conducted to investigate the effect of processing conditions on the mechanical properties of SLM 718. It was found that for these laser parameters, while the material met ultimate tensile strength and yield strength requirements per AMS 5662, the strain-to-failure was reduced with negative focus shift due to increases in porosity levels. It was also found that while correlations were observed between surface roughness, density, and porosity within the laser focus shift range investigated, porosity measurement appears to be the clearest indicator of build quality for AM processed 718.
summary: Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser melting

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-2
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content: The development of various additive manufacturing (AM) technologies is being pursued for numerous industries and applications, such as medical devices, orthopedics, thermal control, aeronautical, space launch, and spaceflight [1–5]. AM processing enables the ability to produce complex geometries, reduce component counts, improve economics of small production runs, and dramatically reduce lead times in production environments [1,3,6,7]. In particular, the laser powder-bed fusion method known as selective laser melting (SLM) is under widespread development due to its capability for improved quality and freedom in designing and manufacturing complex geometries [1,6–11].

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-3
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content: Published research has shown that SLM material attributes such as surface roughness and internal porosity are driven primarily by laser scanning strategy and shielding gas flow, and can be minimized by controlling the energy density via laser parameter tuning [10,12–18]. Energy density is a function of laser power, scan speed, and scan spacing and is responsible for porosity levels in as-printed parts, and can be described by Eqs (1)–(3) in Section 3. Designs of experiments typically adjust these three parameters to understand their influence on porosity. Lower scan speeds and smaller scan spacing providing higher energy density, which is usually associated with lower porosity [10,12,14,19]. Laser parameters can also influence surface roughness, but reduced side wall surface roughness requires lower energy density input to reduce melt pool size and surface tension variation within the melt pool [20]. Laser settings can thus be optimized to yield faster build rates, lower porosity, or better surface finish, depending on the requirements of the application. Additional influence of equipment on porosity and surface finish have been controlled through scan strategies [14] and process gas flow [19]. Ultimately, processing conditions that reduce the scale and amount of porosity will benefit both static and dynamic mechanical properties [10,11,21,22].

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-4
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Furthermore, it is anticipated that most alloys processed by SLM for aerospace and other high-strength, high reliability applications will also require the use of hot isostatic pressing (HIP) to reduce porosity. The amount and type of as-built porosity and its relationship to process parameters is critical and must also be considered when manufacturing AM metallic hardware. Developing an understanding of what size and degree of porosity can be consolidated during HIP is highly beneficial to process engineers when optimizing print conditions in order to produce high-quality parts. Pores that cannot be closed by HIP, whether because they are connected to the surface or are too large to close effectively, would likely be detrimental to the mechanical behavior of selective laser melting-produced Inconel 718 (SLM 718).

One alternate method to improve surface roughness and possibly reduce porosity when printing with a locked OEM parameter set is by changing the energy density via the laser focal height shift, which can be adjusted just as laser power, scan speed or scan spacing. To adequately melt the powder and form parts of acceptable quality the energy density and spot size of the laser are important. An appropriately tuned laser must have a spot size small enough to meet dimensional tolerances, but also supply enough energy density to melt the current powder layer and fuse to the previously melted metal, in the case of the M2 this is a three-layer depth. Energy density can be altered by modifying variables within the machine’s laser parameter set [10,13–15], but if only a locked set is available, the energy density can be effectively varied by modifying the laser focus shift.

![](images/c3b2e2b89c4cee6d2936247ec8dbe571e90035db40ea27f714eac497a1964fd8.jpg)  
Fig. 1. Laser focus shift changes build plate height, affects spot size, energy density at melt pool.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-5
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
![](images/3c84c8585ad3a9ff1c637a0a1a72a2faa83cf42b721da1566c21a39165546088.jpg)  
Fig. 2. Inverted pyramid sample geometry, showing labels built into sample, sectioning plane for metallographic analysis.

Laser focus shift describes the distance that the build plate is moved above or below the user-calibrated zero-plane of the system before the current layer is printed. Positive shifts move the build plate below the zero-plane (increased distance from laser) while negative shifts move the build plate above zero as shown in Fig. 1. While this is a different approach compared with directly changing the three main scan parameters previously discussed, changes in focus shift will vary the effective laser energy density by changing the spot size. Adjusting the focus shift has not been discussed in the same manner as modifying other parameters, but in related work, the focal offset of the beam in electron beam melting has been found to influence similar properties in Ti-6Al

4 V [12].

The aim of this study is to determine the effect of laser focus shift on the surface quality, density, and porosity of specimens produced using SLM processing and understanding how these characteristics affect mechanical performance. To study these effects, a build plate and witness sample geometry was designed so that an array of samples were built at varying lateral positions throughout the build plate and with varying laser focus shifts. These specimens were characterized to determine surface roughness, porosity, and density values before and after HIP treatment. Mechanical properties such as tensile strength and failure strain were also evaluated as a function of laser focus shift to determine which material characteristics are the best indicators in predicting build quality.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-6
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
All parts manufactured in this study were fabricated using a Concept Laser M2 instrument. The specimens were built in a nitrogen environment at a laser power of $3 7 0 W$ , scan rate of $9 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ , and focused spot size of $5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The input models were designed using Solid works, exported as STL files to Magics software, which was used to design build plate layout, add specimen labels, and build supports before using the Concept Laser Slicer module to export CLS files for import to the M2 system. Inverted pyramid specimens were chosen as test configurations and printed in an 11-by-5 matrix, as described below, with the middle column centered on the plate, a horizontal spacing of $3 \mathrm { c m }$ , and a vertical spacing of $2 \mathrm { c m }$ as shown in Figs. 2 and 3. This witness sample geometry was designed so an array of samples could be built at varying lateral position and with varying laser focus shifts.

![](images/a4ce6eddbba3b51ada8aba3816d8f0450cb71a0fa90384fc46e339d1ebe835d0.jpg)  
Fig. 3. Image of build plate showing layout of inverted pyramids as well as rods sub-size tensile testing on build plate and their labeling conventions.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-7
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Each row corresponds to an individual focus shift ranging from $- 5 \mathrm { m m }$ to $+ ~ 5 \mathrm { m m }$ , and each specimen was labeled with a unique identifier which indicates their position and parameter. In this manuscript, specimens are referred to by their shorthand designator, such as $+ 1 \mathsf { A }$ , which means laser focus shift of $+ 1 \mathrm { m m }$ in position “A”, 6 cm left-of-center on the build plate. All pyramids were manufactured for microstructural analysis, porosity determination, surface roughness along different orientations, and real density measurements. In addition to the 55 inverted pyramids, a total of $3 0 \ : 6 . 3 5 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ diameter rods were printed at laser focus shifts of −3, 0, and $+ \ 3 \mathrm { m m }$ at varying locations on the build plate for metallographic analysis and sub-size tensile testing. The layout of the inverted pyramids and sub-size rods can be seen in Fig. 3.

This study was conducted using Inconel 718 powder (CL100), supplied by Concept Laser. Independent powder analysis shows the as-received powder meets AMS 5662 nominal composition limits for Inconel 718 [23], and has particle size distribution of $1 0 { - } 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , with mean size of $3 4 . 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , ${ \bf d } _ { 1 0 }$ of $2 3 . 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , and ${ \bf d } _ { 9 0 }$ of $4 6 . 1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . Before use for this build, the powder was sieved twice using a $6 8 \mathrm { - } \mu \mathrm { m }$ mesh pneumatic system to

ensure uniformity.

Surface roughness was characterized via stylus profilometery on vertical and downward-angled faces of pyramids using a Taylor Hobson Talysurf PGI 1220. Samples were held using a vice, measurements were taken over a length of $3 . 6 \mathrm { m m }$ , and were slope corrected with no filtering. Average roughness measurements (Ra) ranged from 5 to $6 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-8
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Real density measurements were obtained by performing a liquid Archimedes method as defined by ASTM B962 [24]. A Mettler Toledo 33360 density measurement kit, with a $5 0 0 \mathrm { m L }$ water bath and a Mettler AE163 scale with $0 . 0 1 \mathrm { m g }$ resolution were used for all measurements, and water temperature was recorded.

Image analysis was conducted to characterize the porosity size and distribution within the specimen. NIH Image J version 1.51j was used to quantify porosity levels by using a contrast slice method. Measurements were conducted on specimen sectioned in half along the vertical axis and polished to a surface finish of $0 . 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , using a minimum of five micrographs taken at higher magnification on a Nikon Epiphot inverted metallographic microscope.

Selected inverted pyramid samples and all rods for tensile specimens were HIP treated at $1 1 6 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $1 0 2 0 \mathrm { a t m }$ for $^ { 3 \mathrm { h } }$ , and heat treated according to AMS 5662 (Solution treated at $9 5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 1 \mathrm { h } }$ , water quenched, then precipitation treated at $7 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $^ { 8 \mathrm { h } }$ followed by furnace cool at $5 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C / h r }$ to $6 2 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and hold for total cycle time of $^ { 1 8 \mathrm { h } }$ ). Sub-size tensile dogbone specimen were machined from heat treated rods to final dimensions of $3 . 1 7 5 \mathrm { m m }$ gauge diameter and $1 2 . 7 \mathrm { m m }$ gauge length, with fillet radius of $1 2 . 7 \mathrm { m m }$ . All tensile specimens were tested on an Instron Model No. 55R1115 Universal Testing Machine using a $5 0 ~ \mathrm { k i p }$ load cell, at a test rate of $0 . 1 \mathrm { { m m / m m / m i n } }$ , and an

Instron clip-on extensometer (cat. No. 2620-824) was used for failure strain determination. Instron Bluehill 3 software was used for test control, data capture, and export. All specimen geometries and testing methods were compliant with ASTM E8 [25].

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-10
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Analysis of profilometry data reveals that focus shift values of $^ { + 3 }$ to $+ 5 \mathrm { m m }$ produced the smoothest surfaces, with roughness dependent on the lateral position. At focus shifts of $\pm \ 2 \mathrm { m m }$ and below, the surfaces appeared relatively rough and were well beyond the measurement capability of the surface characterization instrument used in this study $( > 6 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , so these samples were excluded from further roughness analysis. As previously described, the inverted pyramid coupons were printed with numerical details both on the top faces as well as on the vertical sides to better evaluate surface quality. Fig. 4A shows examples of these coupons with the clear legible numerical labels on the top faces. However, the labels on the vertical faces varied in clarity and resolution with increasing roughness for some of the laser focus shifts. Initial visual inspection of the pyramids revealed a distinct variation in surface roughness with respect to the laser focus shift parameter as well as to the position within each row.

Surface roughness of the vertical $( 9 0 ^ { \circ } )$ and downward angled $( \sim 6 5 ^ { \circ } )$ faces (referred to in this manuscript as “vertical” and “angled” faces, respectively) was measured with a profilometer. Average roughness (Ra) and root-mean-square roughness (Rq) were measured and analyzed. For smoother samples, the vertical faces were significantly smoother than angled faces (Ra of $5 \mathrm { - } 1 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ compared with $2 0 { - } 2 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ ), though for rougher specimens the reverse was true, as illustrated by measurements obtained from samples $+ 4 \mathbf { B }$ and $+ 4 \mathrm { E }$ , respectively, as shown in Fig. 4b and c.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-11
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content: Roughness measurements of vertical and angled faces for rows $+ 3$ $+ 4$ , and $^ { + 5 }$ were plotted and show increased roughness on the right side of the build plate when compared to the left side as shown in Fig. 5. Roughness of vertical faces exhibited a non-linear variation across the build plate with observed minima at both “B” and $^ { \mathfrak { e } } \mathbf { D } ^ { \mathfrak { p } }$ positions $( \pm \ : 3 \mathrm { c m }$ from center) for all three rows. In contrast, there is a roughly linear increase in roughness of angled faces across the build plate.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-12
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Surface roughness is controlled by a number of factors such as laser calibration, laser power, scanning parameters, and gas flow. Since all of the laser settings were held constant during the build, we believe the uneven variation in surface roughness across the build plate is due to an unstable flow of the protective gas across the build plate. A schematic representation of gas flow path in the build chamber can be seen in Fig. 6. Although positive laser focus shifts in the $^ { + 3 }$ to $+ 5 \mathrm { m m }$ range resulted in a reduction in average surface roughness for vertical and angled faces, the roughness variation across the build plate (Fig. 5) indicates that adjusting the laser focus may lead to turbulent gas flow. It has been shown that inhomogeneous protective gas flow, such as is produced in turbulent flow conditions, can lead to increased surface roughness due to insufficient removal of process byproducts and interaction of the laser with these byproducts [8,9]. These focus shifts correspond to the build plate being shifted downward $3 { - } 5 \mathrm { m m }$ below the plane of the build chamber which changes the gas flow path considerably and introduces the possibility of turbulent flow, analogous to gas flow over a blind hole where areas near the edges would not experience the same type of environment as those in adjacent areas. The smoothest measured surface was sample $+ 3 \mathrm { D }$ $( \mathrm { R a } = 5 . 1 5 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , however the focus shift that produced the overall smoothest samples at all positions was $+ ~ 5 \mathrm { m m }$ (average $\mathrm { R a } = 2 1 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m } $ .

![](images/67671c186cb468dfc7fc275e48550b25e94ca394c2eb7866004b5b82cd1f70d0.jpg)  
Fig. 5. Average roughness (Ra) measurements across build plate for (A) vertical and (B) angled faces.

![](images/2bf9ae6867c417fc666b8b9bd9702a03be6460fa1336352c6eac438bd6921a6d.jpg)  
Fig. 6. Gas flow over build plate in Concept Laser M2.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-13
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Density measurements were performed on all samples printed at focus shifts of $+ 3 , \ + 4$ , and $+ 5 \mathrm { m m }$ , in the as-printed condition. Density measurements exhibit a non-linear variation across the build plate and an inverse relationship with surface roughness (Figs. 7 and 8). This suggests that a similar mechanism may be responsible for both surface roughness and density variations, and may be related to the coupling of laser focus and protective gas flow.

The images in Fig. 9 illustrate the large variation observed in porosity levels with respect to the focus shift level. It should be noted that the large gaps observed on the top surface of the samples are due to the numerical labels printed into the surface, not porosity. Porosity levels were significantly higher for negative laser focus shifts, with the highest porosity measured in the sample printed at $- 2 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift $( 7 . 1 \% )$ and lowest porosity levels observed in the $+ 5 \mathrm { - m m }$ shift sample $( 0 . 8 1 \% )$ . Specimens printed at $^ { + 1 }$ and $+ 5 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift have less than $1 \%$ as-printed porosity, while samples printed at $+ 2 , + 3 , + 4 { \mathrm { - m m } }$ shifts appear to deviate from any linear trend. This non-linear behavior in as-printed porosity can best be understood by analyzing the type and degree of porosity in the specimen as well as considering the effect of focus shift with respect to the laser optics.

![](images/582d410855d4e3679b76afdad3159cd289600248797867a92a97c228029cd47b.jpg)  
Fig. 7. As-printed density of inverted pyramid specimen printed at $+ 3 , \ + 4 ,$ , $+ 5 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift.

![](images/c0e2d5ef418d314833487c83572fd84d2b4f9bafe9a5f6bfb5d9cc5fcaaecc6a.jpg)  
Fig. 8. Correlation of as-printed density with surface roughness.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-14
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
In order to better understand the correlations between porosity and laser energy density, as controlled by laser focus shift, we can look to the laser beam characteristics. The effect of laser focus shift on laser energy density input via spot size is directly related to the divergence of the Gaussian distribution of the system’s laser beam. The following divergence equations can be used to calculate the change in spot size with relative motion of the build plate towards or away from the laser. Power density at the build plate surface can be described by the

![](images/120aff657ce53b93d9ec7e4dc18b8b48c81676f30a2f93ee90f2ef26eb37c824.jpg)  
Fig. 9. Variation in as-printed porosity due to laser focus shift.

equation:

$$
P D = { \sqrt [ { P } ] { \pi \omega ^ { 2 } } }
$$

where $P$ is the laser output power and $\omega$ is the laser spot size radius, which is described by the function:

$$
\omega ( z ) = \omega _ { 0 } \sqrt { 1 + \left( \frac { z } { Z _ { r } } \right) ^ { 2 } }
$$

where $\omega _ { 0 }$ is the minimum laser spot size, corresponding to the laser focal point, $z$ is the distance from the laser focal point, and $Z _ { r }$ is the Rayleigh length. This can be calculated using the equation:

$$
Z _ { r } = \frac { \pi { \omega _ { 0 } } ^ { 2 } } { \lambda }
$$

where $\lambda$ is the laser wavelength. The Rayleigh length is the distance from the laser focal point, where the spot size area is doubled, halving the power density. The Concept Laser M2 uses a Ytterbium continuous fiber laser with nominal wavelength $\lambda = 1 0 7 0 n m$ and the Rayleigh distance is calculated to be $1 . 8 3 5 \mathrm { m m }$ . Using this information, the laser spot size variation and power density attenuation can be plotted with respect to the build plate focus shift in the Concept Laser M2 (Fig. 10).

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-15
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Laser energy density is highest at the laser focal point and attenuates with laser focus shift. By overlaying the results of porosity analysis with a relative power density curve and correlating with the types of porosity observed, the symmetry of these results can be used to infer a laser focal point near the $+ 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ build shift position (Fig. 11). At low focus shift values, such as the specimen printed at $- 2 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift, large, connected porosity and un-melted powder particles within the internal cavities are produced during the printing process (Fig. 12a). This level of irregularly-shaped porosity, taken with small amounts of un-melted powder within the pores indicates a lack of fusion due to insufficient laser energy at the melt pool. As the build plate is brought closer to the laser focal plane, increased power density improves consolidation, and the morphology of porosity changes to smaller, more dispersed gas bubble porosity, as observed in specimen printed at $^ { + 1 }$ - mm focus shift (Fig. 12b). As the focus shift continues to increase, the power density increases further, and excessive energy at the melt pool causes keyhole porosity as shown in Fig. 12c for the specimen printed at $+ 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift. Increasing the focus shift to $+ 5 \mathrm { m m }$ again reduces laser power density to levels more ideal for consolidation (Fig. 12d).

![](images/a2a4857c57d453dc74ac5297818ac436a6524a7e770eb5d3296528d6393f8dd1.jpg)  
Fig. 10. - Variation in laser spot size and power density, calculated with respect to build focus shift.

![](images/b7aa120b8da2d5605c94368b67d393f4fbb030c2db1486b331a32ae56504f42a.jpg)  
Fig. 11. Variation in as-printed porosity levels with respect to laser focus shift; micrographs labeled with porosity levels.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-16
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
![](images/b9c50c2422a7140bd4b2d9df95a3a212a2672e044071172aaf6e2761afb60bb0.jpg)  
Fig. 12. Detail of porosity morphology observed in SLM 78 witness specimen printed at (a) $- 2 \mathbf { m } \mathbf { m }$ , (b $) + 1 \mathrm { m m }$ , ( $\mathrm { \Delta \ s } ) + 3 \mathrm { m m }$ , and (d) $+ 5 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shifts.

In order to improve the density of printed parts, hot isostatic pressing (HIP) is typically employed to close internal porosity. Samples were processed with a standard Inconel $7 1 8 ~ \mathrm { H I P }$ cycle as described in the experimental section. Analysis of density and porosity measurements before and after HIP treatment shows that while effective at closing gas bubble porosity, HIP is not effective at closing larger keyhole porosity or connected pores seen in $+ 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ and $+ 4 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shifts. Density measurements of HIP treated specimens show an average increase of $0 . 2 6 \mathrm { g } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 3 }$ , which corresponds with reductions in porosity between $2 3 \%$ for the $+ 4 \mathrm { - m m }$ specimen and $8 5 \%$ for the $+ 5 \mathrm { - m m }$ specimen, as illustrated in Fig. 13. Correlation of density and porosity numbers, as shown in Fig. 14, illustrates that below approximately $1 \%$ porosity, differences in density measurements are not perceptive to small changes in porosity.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-17
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content: Along with laser settings, shielding gas flow uniformity has been shown to have the largest impact on process stability and material quality in SLM parts [8,9,13]. Shielding gas flow serves to remove process by-products produced during the melting process, which include ejected powder, spatter, metal vapor, condensate, and the plasma plume. Low gas flow leads to re-deposition of by-products onto the build surface as well as interaction of the laser beam with the byproducts, resulting in attenuation of the laser beam and degradation of surface and bulk material quality. Examining the differences between specimen $+ 4 \mathrm { B }$ and $+ 4 \mathrm { E }$ shown in Fig. 5 displays this effect. We believe the visibly increased surface roughness of sample $+ 4 \mathrm { E }$ is due to ejected powder and spatter not being effectively removed by gas flow and consequently becoming fused to the part surfaces. Positioning of the build plate far from the base level of the build chamber increases the likelihood of uneven flow across the build plate, especially without sufficient flow velocity. When the laser beam is attenuated by the welding plume, less energy reaches the powder surface and penetrates the powder, which can lead to the formation of larger spherical particles of molten metal rather than fusion with the powder bed, a phenomenon known as balling [9]. This condition is seen in Fig. 12a. Additionally, if gas flow is not sufficient to carry ejected powder and metal vapor away from the melt pool, the re-deposited material will produce a thicker layer nearby, which will be melted on following laser passes. Even without attenuation of the laser beam, it may not be possible to fuse this additional material to the powder bed below. This will similarly lead to formation of larger spherical particles on the surface.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-18
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
This balling phenomenon is also commonly seen in lower laser power regimes [8,9,15], which explains why it is observed at regions of the build plate which have lower laser energy (below $+ 2 { \cdot } \mathrm { m m }$ focus shift) as well as in regions with uneven gas flow.

![](images/6a9e651d0ae7ddca34b3c7a1b3a60e40dce270271b726023060e81296cf8f83e.jpg)  
Fig. 14. Correlation of porosity and density measurements.

![](images/957665601aeb250d65066f6bcd5abb3ba632e6232900f60ca6d444bfd634ba08.jpg)  
Fig. 13. Porosity levels of specimen printed at $+ 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ , $+ 4 { \cdot } \mathrm { m m }$ , and $+ 5 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift in (A) the as-printed condition and (B) after HIP treatment.

For the Concept Laser M2 SLM system, gas flow is controlled as a blower speed percentage rather than an output volumetric flow rate. However, based on this system’s specified maximum flow rate volumetric flow rate is on the order of $4 5 \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 } / h$ when blower speed is set to $7 0 \%$ . Gas flow path has a large influence over the flow rate and uniformity over the build plate. Fig. 6 shows an illustration of the gas path in the M2, but without detailed modeling of the build chamber and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis, it is difficult to quantify the flow over the build plate. However, it has been found that increasing gas flow rate and improving the gas flow path through modification of inlet and/or chamber geometry improves material quality and decreases variation in surface roughness and porosity [8,9,11,14].

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-19
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Finally, to better understand the effect of laser focus shift on mechanical properties, rods were printed at $+ 3 , 0$ , and $- 3 \mathbf { m m }$ laser focus shift. These specimens were heat treated and machined into round tensile specimens and tested at room temperature as described in the experimental section. Tensile samples were taken from four positions on the build plate: top-left (TL), middle-left (ML), top-right (TR), and middle-right (MR), as illustrated in Fig. 3. Visual inspection of the rods in the as-printed condition showed rougher surfaces on the right side of the build plate and increasing roughness with lower laser focus shifts. This is in line with the trends observed from the witness pyramids. Even though surfaces were machined away before testing, this may still provide a first indication of internal material quality.

Tensile testing revealed position and focus shift dependence of mechanical properties. All specimen met yield and ultimate tensile strength requirements, per AMS 5662, exceeding them by $1 4 \%$ and $6 . 5 \%$ , respectively, for the lowest strength specimen, as reported in Table 1. However, elongation and reduction in area requirements were not met by a number of specimen. The only samples that met both requirements were printed on the left-hand side of the build plate at 0- mm and $+ 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift, and the sample printed in the MR position at $+ 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-20
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content: To gain a better understanding of these mechanical property variations, cross sections of tested specimen were mounted to evaluate the degree of porosity as well as variations in morphology between samples. Samples printed on the left-hand side have lower porosity than corresponding samples on the right-hand side, at all focus shifts. At porosity levels below $^ { 1 \% }$ , porosity is typically small, circular, and disconnected, which is indicative of gas bubble porosity. At the highest levels (samples printed at $- 3 \mathrm { - m m }$ focus shift) there are large, connected voids with unconsolidated powder visible. This is consistent with porosity observed in the inverted pyramids printed at negative focus shifts, which also showed high porosity levels. The low density and higher porosity measurements correlate well with the lower observed elongation and reduction in area values. This indicates while all samples met yield and ultimate strength requirements after heat treatment, elevated porosity levels are responsible for reduced elongation. Therefore, low elongation at room temperature may be considered a reliable indicator of gross defects within SLM 718 specimens.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-21
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
An array of specimens were built at varying laser focus shift heights to determine the effects of laser focus shift and position on the build plate on material quality. Material density, porosity, surface roughness, and room-temperature tensile properties were characterized. All room temperature tensile test specimens met yield and ultimate strength requirements and appeared to be insensitive to higher porosity levels. However, the higher-porosity samples did not meet elongation and area reduction requirements. This indicates that room temperature ductility of tensile specimens may be more perceptive of material quality issues than strength for SLM 718. This may be a result of Inconel 718 being a precipitation-strengthened alloy which benefits from the standard heat treatment regardless of porosity level.

Variations in the amount and degree of porosity with respect to focus shift can be related to the power density distribution due to attenuation of the Gaussian laser optics. For the output laser power used in this study, the ideal power density for consolidation is at roughly one Rayleigh distance, which suggests that in order for higher-density samples to be built at the focal plane, laser parameter should be adjusted to melt powder with roughly one-half of the power density. Additionally, the porosity type and amount determines whether pores can be closed via HIP treatment. Large connected porosity and unconsolidated powder cannot be corrected, but small discreet gas porosity is effectively closed by HIP treatment. As such, it may not be necessary to perform an exhaustive optimization with the aim of minimizing gas porosity for samples and parts that will be processed via HIP treatment before testing or use.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-22
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content: Protective gas flow within the build chamber may be responsible for lateral position-dependent variations in surface roughness. It was observed that roughness did not increase monotonically across the build plate for vertical surfaces, but instead there was a W-shaped trend with maximum roughness measurements for left, middle, and right positions (positions $^ { \mathfrak { a } } \mathbf { A } ^ { \mathfrak { n } }$ , “C”, and $^ { \mathrm { t } } \mathrm { E } ^ { \mathrm { \prime \prime } } \big ]$ ). Additionally, specimens built far from the laser focal plane exhibited surface roughness that exceeded the measurable threshold the profilometer due to the sintering of particles to printed surfaces at much lower energy input coupled with insufficient removal of process by-products by the protective gas. Modification of the gas flow rate and/or path would improve uniformity of surfaces across build plate. A direct correlation was seen between surface roughness and porosity, and an inverse correlation with density. These findings indicate that density and surface roughness may be used as first-order quality control evaluation methods for determining SLM 718 build soundness.

name: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m-part-23
fileName: 2018 - AM - Bean et al. - Effect of laser focus shift on surface quality and density of Inconel 718 parts produced via selective laser m.md
content:
Printer settings such as laser power and focal height interact with system gas flow within the build chamber to influence resulting material quality. A large focus shift may be necessary to reach the desired location with respect to laser optics, but simultaneously may create detrimental gas flow conditions, introducing turbulent flow or no-flow areas. Likewise, the optimal focus shift position is dictated by laser parameters such as output power and scanning speed. Therefore, these results are a first step towards optimization of not only laser parameters but machine setup, and illustrate that even prior to performing an indepth laser parameter development study the user can have a large amount of control over both internal porosity and surface quality by modifying laser spot size via laser focus shift. By tuning the laser focus shift and evaluating its effects on print quality, the relative improvements in average density of our SLM 718 samples was $1 . 5 \%$ , surface roughness was decreased by $2 8 \%$ , and porosity was reduced by $9 7 \%$ .

Table 1 Physical properties of tested sub-size tensile samples.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-1
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
# Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling
D. Brown, C. Li, Z. Y. Liu, X. Y. Fang & Y. B. Guo

To cite this article: D. Brown, C. Li, Z. Y. Liu, X. Y. Fang & Y. B. Guo (2018) Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling, Virtual and Physical Prototyping, 13:1, 26-31, DOI: 10.1080/17452759.2017.1392681

To link to this article: https://doi.org/10.1080/17452759.2017.1392681

# Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling
D. Browna \*, C. Lia \*, Z. Y. Liua , X. Y. Fangb and Y. B. Guoa

a Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, USA; b Institute for Advanced Manufacturing, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, People’s Republic of China

# ABSTRACT
While selective laser melting (SLM) offers design freedom of metal parts with much less material consumption, there exist several limitations, including high surface roughness, low-dimensional accuracy, and high tensile residual stresses. To make functional parts with high form accuracy and superior surface integrity, an as-SLM part needs finishing to remove the deposited surface material. The integration of machining and SLM creates a hybrid manufacturing route to overcome the inherited limitations of SLM. However, little study has been done to characterise surface integrity of an as-SLM part followed by machining (e.g. hybrid SLM-milling). In this paper, surface, integrity including surface roughness, microstructure, and microhardness, have been characterised for IN718 samples processed by the hybrid process. It has been found that microhardness varies with the scan direction and the use of coolant in the subsequent milling, and surface integrity can be significantly improved by the hybrid SLM-milling route.

ARTICLE HISTORY Received 26 September 2017 Accepted 8 October 2017

# KEYWORDS
Surface integrity; selective laser melting; machining; hybrid manufacturing
summary: ABSTRACT, KEYWORDS, Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-2
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
The widely used additive manufacturing (AM) process to manufacture metal parts is selective laser melting (SLM), which consists of the use of a laser to melt metallic powders in a layer-by-layer fashion. While SLM allows new freedoms and possibilities in terms of design, there exist several limitations due to the process nature. Most of these limitations arise from the high thermal gradient in the melt pool, which leads to poor dimensional accuracy, high surface roughness, high porosity (Gu et al. 2012), and tensile residual stresses (Kruth et al. 2012, Li et al. 2016).

The improvement of surface integrity of SLM part can be manifested in two ways: process optimisation and post-processing of an SLMed part. Gu et al. (2012) summarised studies with focus on optimising process parameters such as laser power, laser speed, powder layer thickness, substrate temperature, powder bed temperature, and scanning strategy. Additionally, the effects of post-processing techniques such as heat treatment have been studied for several metallic powders and processes (Li et al. 2017a). Rolling process was used during AM to obtain smaller grain size and superior mechanical properties (Xie et al. 2016). Recently, laser shock peening has been used in SLM to control the residual stress profile of the final part (Sealy et al. 2016, Kalentics et al. 2017). The use of machining as post-processing to improve surface finish has been applied in directed energy deposition process for decades (Jeng and Lin 2001). Limited research has been focused on the surface integrity of part by hybrid SLM-machining.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-3
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content: The integration of machining with SLM creates a hybrid manufacturing route that may overcome the pressing problems of poor surface finish and lowdimensional accuracy inherent of an SLMed part. In this paper, the effects of machining on surface integrity of SLMed IN718 samples were studied. The goal of this study was to provide basic understanding of the hybrid process and provide preliminary results in realising the potential improvements of surface integrity for a SLMed part via the integration of a machining process.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-4
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
For this study, an in-house developed SLM system was used to fabricate the IN718 samples. Each sample was made to have the dimensions of $2 5 ~ \mathsf { m m }$ $\mathrm { ( L ) } \times 1 0 \ : \mathrm { m m }$ $( \mathsf { W } ) \times 3 \mathsf { m m }$ (H). A detailed SLM set-up could be accessed in reference (Li et al. 2017b). The laser power was $8 0 W ,$ scan speed was $1 5 0 0 \ : \mathrm { m m / m i n } ,$ and scan spacing was $1 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . Figure 1(a) shows the milling set-up. Figure 1(b) shows the scanning patterns used in SLM. In this study, totally six samples were fabricated: Sample #1, #2, and #5 were deposited along length direction, while samples #3, #4, and #6 in the across direction. Sample #5 and #6 were in as-SLM state, samples #1 and $\# 3$ were used for conducting flood cutting while samples #2 and $\# 4$ for dry cutting.

![](images/cdaa9f0aa56a603f8095451a54094bba44044171e6ca197f46c8cdbcaf2871a0.jpg)  
(a) Milling set-up, (b) scanning patterns, (c) sample sectioning and mounting.

The top layer of SLMed samples was first removed before the milling experiment. Then, each sample was machined using down milling condition as follows: cutting speed of $6 0 \mathrm { \ m / m i n }$ feed per tooth of $0 . 1 5 ~ \mathrm { m } / $ min, radial DoC of $0 . 5 ~ \mathsf { m m }$ , and axial DoC of $0 . 5 ~ \mathsf { m m }$ . The cutting direction was along the length of the sample, as shown in Figure 1(b). As shown in Figure 1 (c), the samples were sectioned, ground, finishing polished using a $1 ~ \mu \mathrm { m }$ diamond suspension, and then electro-etched using $7 0 ~ \mathsf { m l }$ phosphoric acid and $3 0 ~ \mathsf { m l }$ water with a voltage of $5 \lor$ for $5 s$ .

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-7
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
# 3.1. Microstructure and defects
Figure 2(a) shows the YZ cross-section of dry machined sample 4. This image shows the laser passes travelling horizontally across the page. These passes were distinctly separate from each other, with most boundaries being dictated by laser passes, rather than by the naturally occurring grains in the microstructure. Some small porosities can also be seen here, with sizes ranging from 10 to $5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . Figure 2(b) shows the XZ cross-section of sample 5. This can be seen by the series of overlapping semi-circular patterns which are formed due to the solidification of melt pool from each laser pass. Figure 2(b) shows a uniform distribution of laser passes, with clear overlaps and limited voids. Another notable cause of voids in the part is the balling effect. The balling effect is the tendency of a molten liquid to become a sphere due to the surface tension of the liquid. An example of the balling effect is shown in Figure 2(c). Scan speed and laser power are the two significant factors that contribute to balling. Balling effect can be limited by process parameter optimisation. Figure 2(d) shows an example of the balling effect in a void with a length of almost $8 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . While multiple factors likely lead to its formation, the size in many ways was added by the formation of the balls. When analysing the depth of this void, it can be seen to retreat slightly over $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ into the surface. A void in this size would greatly affect the fatigue life of a part, and could be a safety concern depending on the part’s loading and importance.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-8
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
Figure 3(a,b) shows the surface topography before and after milling. The change in height is not proportional to the XY directions for fully observing the difference. As shown in Figure 3(a), the roughness is found to be exceptionally high, with a total height change of $5 1 1 \ \mu \mathrm { m } _ { i }$ , over half a millimetre. It should also be noted that this height change is consistent across the image. Figure 3(b) shows the surface topography of the same sample after milling, which shows that improving surface finish of a SLMed part is where the usefulness of machining truly shines.

The measured $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ data for samples 1–4 are shown in Figure 3(c). Each machined sample was measured five times in both X and Y directions (Figure 1(c)), and the average value and standard deviation were provided.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-9
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content: The roughness of the as-SLM samples was too large to be measured using the Dektak IIA measuring system. Three findings were made. The first is in comparing the resulting $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ vales with flood and dry milling. On average, dry milling resulted in lower $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values by $0 . 1 1 3 \mu \mathrm { m } ,$ , or $2 3 . 6 \%$ . This suggests that dry machining would typically create a better surface finish in SLM parts. Next the average measurements in the scan and step-over directions were compared. The $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values were found to be lower by $0 . 0 8 \mu \mathsf { m } _ { i }$ , or $1 6 . 8 \%$ , when measured in the step-over direction. The last comparison involved investigating any possible interactions between the cutting and scan directions. This analysis found that lower $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values occurred when the cutting direction and scan direction aligned, with a percent difference in this case of $6 . 8 \%$ . It should be noted that the average standard deviation is $0 . 1 1 \ \mu \mathsf { m }$ , which reduces the significance of these findings. This high variability is most likely due to the irregular positioning of the porosities.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-10
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content: The $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values after milling for SLM samples were compared against conventionally fabricated IN718. The following data were measured from samples that had been machined with coolant under the same cutting conditions (Li et al. 2014): $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values measured in cutting and perpendicular to cutting direction is 0.15 and $0 . 1 6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , respectively. It shows that the SLMed samples with cutting direction both perpendicular and parallel to the scan direction have higher $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values. These values signify a percent increase of $2 6 0 \%$ and $2 4 7 \%$ in comparison to the conventionally manufactured parts. Comparing the $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values measured perpendicular to the cutting direction shows similar results. The SLM sample which had a cutting direction perpendicular to the scan direction has an $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ value that is $0 . 4 1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ greater than that of the conventional sample, and the SLM sample which had a cutting direction parallel to the scan direction has an $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ value that is $0 . 1 2 \mu \mathrm { m }$ greater than that of the conventional sample. These changes represent increases of $2 5 6 \%$ and $7 5 \%$ , respectively. High $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values in the SLMed samples are due to the porosity in the parts. On average, the SLM samples have $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values that are $2 1 9 \%$ greater than those of the conventionally manufactured samples.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-11
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
The porosity discussed above contributes greatly to the overall variation of hardness of the samples. As part of this study, the changes in hardness values at depth due to the machining passes were investigated. Chatterjee et al. (2003) found the hardness of an SLMed tool steel to be a direct result of the part porosity, and it can be assumed that the porosity of other materials plays a large role in their hardness. This assumption can be validated through hardness tests. Figure 4(a–c) shows optical images of hardness indentation tests. All hardness tests were conducted using a load of $2 5 0 { \mathfrak { g } }$ and duration of $1 5 s .$ .

![](images/1496a6c93404fdd4245744551d028779c2da45af8252f0d81ca2591a34da5bb3.jpg)  
(a) Surface topography of sample 1 prior to milling; (b) after milling; (c) surface roughness $R _ { \mathfrak { a } }$ values of the machined samples.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-12
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content: As shown in Figure 4(a), a slight increase in indentation size was observed because of proximity to a void, proving the relationship between hardness and porosity. A decrease in Vickers Hardness of $1 0 8 . 8 5 \ \mathsf { H V }$ for the top indent pair and a decrease of $1 1 8 . 2 0 \ \mathsf { H V }$ for the bottom indent pair. There exist several possible reasons for this change. The first is the proximity to the porosity, as the ability of the material to support itself could be compromised by the void. The second is the tendency of material to ‘fold over’ voids during indentation tests. This third possibility is due to the $\gamma ^ { \prime \prime }$ phase, which largely contributes to the hardness in IN718. It is possible that imperfect melting and solidification of the IN718 particles could cause changes in the properties of the microstructure. Throughout the course of the hardness testing, other low hardness zones were also found. The largest zone is shown in Figure 4(b). In this example, the center-left indentation is notably larger than any others in its vicinity, especially those at the same depth. The difference in hardness measurement between this indent and its counterpart $8 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ to its right is $2 8 0 \ \mathsf { H V } ,$ , representing a decrease from 423 to 143 HV. While hardness values can be theoretically improved at the surface through machining, the influence of porosity and voids cannot be negated. The final area which showed fluctuations in hardness is in the area close to the substrate. In all samples tested, the lowest hardness values (excluding the outlier shown in Figure 4(b)) were always found at the part–substrate interface. On average, the indentations along the substrate line were $1 4 . 3 \%$ lower than those throughout the rest of the sample, representing a decrease on average from about 396 HV to $3 3 9 \ \mathsf { H V } .$ As shown in Figure 4(c), a rippling effect can be seen around each indentation.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-13
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
This relates to the low hardness along the part–substrate interface.

![](images/e78d433df7fec66b59c3aac6ba199c40db5bc9154f309645925020fde940cb38.jpg)  
(a) Microhardness test on YZ cross-section of sample 3; (b) YZ cross-section of sample 5; (c) part–substrate interface of YZ Figure 4.cross-section of sample 5; (d) Microhardness profile along depth direction before and after machining.

Figure 4(d) shows the hardness profile along the depth direction into the subsurface. Brinksmeier et al. (2010) found the depth of influence of machining to be around $4 0 \mu \mathrm { m } ;$ however, he had difficulty in getting accurate measurements at this depth. In this study, the same problem was encountered when using a microhardness indenter. Accurate readings began at around $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } _ { i }$ ; however, there was difficulty in analysing the hardness in the shallow depth region. It is evident that any changes in hardness due to the machining process are hidden in this area. The fluctuations throughout the full profile of the part are most likely due to fluctuations in porosity, and it is the author’s view that all the hardness profiles shown above would approach an ideal line as the SLM process is refined and optimised.

name: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling-part-14
fileName: 2018 - Virtual and Physical Prototyping - Brown et al. - Surface integrity of Inconel 718 by hybrid selective laser melting and milling.md
content:
# 4. Summary and conclusions
In this study, surface roughness and microstructure before and after machining of SLMed IN718 were characterised. The use of milling was found to result in a smoother surface on average. Other possible interactions between milling, scan, and measurement direction were identified; however, the high variability of the results shows the need for repeat testing, and improvement of process parameters. The microstructure analysis showed porosities, voids, and low hardness zones in the subsurface. The high porosity resulted from imperfect process parameters. By fabricating an SLM part with near-full density, a more accurate analysis of the effects of milling on a part would be possible.

The porosity and microstructure also affected the hardness profile significantly. The most significant finding was the low hardness along the part–substrate interface. The next step will be to analyse the microstructure of this interface more closely to identify any possible phases’ change that may be causing the change in hardness. Also, after optimising the process parameters to create a part of near-full density and then using a nano-indenter to focus on the subsurface zone less than $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , the hardness profile would be much more likely to provide insight into the exact effects of machining. This work is a prelim study on the surface integrity of hybrid SLM-milling process. A further study is planned to investigate more SLM and milling parameters.

# Disclosure statement
No potential conflict of interest was reported by the authors.

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-1
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content:
Full Length Article

# Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing process
Luke Scime⁎ , Jack Beuth

xtManufacturing Center, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Ave., Pittsburgh PA 15213, United S

# A R T I C L E I N F O


# A B S T R A C T
Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing Inconel 718   
Statistical behavior   
Melt pool variability   
Melt pool morphology

Expanding on prior process mapping work by the authors, multiple melt pool cross-sections are measured at multiple process parameter combinations for the Inconel 718 alloy in a Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF) process. Collection of such data enables the study of the variability of melt pool geometry (e.g. width, depth, and cross-sectional area) across process space. Furthermore, the statistical distribution of the measured melt pool geometries is compared to that of an equivalent normal distribution and intriguing outliers are observed. The cross-sectional morphology of the melt pools are associated with defects such as keyholing porosity and balling and the variability of the defects is quantified. The final product of this work is a robust description of L-PBF In718 melt pool behavior, based on ex-situ observations, which can be linked to in-situ observations of melt pool morphology in future work.
summary: Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive manufacturing process 前言

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-2
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: In their endeavors to exploit the design freedoms that come with Additive Manufacturing (AM), designers must push the boundaries of the machine processing parameters. It therefore becomes necessary for them to understand how those parameters impact the final part quality and what kinds of defects and degree of melt pool dimensional and morphological variability they can expect. Currently, AM machine manufacturers offer only a limited set of “approved” processing parameters for each material system, limiting the design freedom of the end user. Beuth and Klingbeil [1] were among the first to study the effects of processing parameters on melt pool geometry in the AM space. Since then, such effects have been studied extensively by many researchers. For example, Promoppatum et al. [2] investigated the influence of laser beam power and velocity on melt pool size and microstructure in the Ti6Al-4V alloy system using both experiments and heat transfer simulations. Similarly, Francis [3] demonstrated the effects of laser beam diameter across multiple steel alloys. Tang et al. [4] discussed the fundamental relationships between laser beam power, travel velocity, and a processing defect known as lack-of-fusion porosity. Despite this large body of extant work, the variability of the melt pool behavior is often left unexplored, often due to the relatively small number of measurements collected. As observed by Clymer [5], such variability could have significant consequences for process parameter design and optimization in real-world scenarios. Furthermore, meaningful interpretation of data from in-situ process monitoring schema often requires correlation with data from ex-situ analyses and this linkage requires a truly representative sampling of melt pool behavior.

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-3
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content:
This work studies melt pool behavior across Laser Powder Bed Fusion (L-PBF) process space for the Inconel 718 $\mathrm { ( I n 7 1 8 ) }$ ) alloy (Ni $5 0 { - } 5 5 \mathrm { w t \% }$ , $\mathrm { C r ~ } 1 7 . 0 { - } 2 1 . 0 \mathrm { w t \% }$ , Nb $4 . 7 5 { - } 5 . 5 \mathrm { w t \% }$ , Mo $2 . 8 \mathrm { - } 3 . 3 \mathrm { w t \% }$ , Ti $0 . 6 5 \mathrm { - } 1 . 1 5 \mathrm { w t \% }$ [6]. In718 is of significant interest to the AM community owing to a variety of desirable material properties including high temperature performance and excellent corrosion resistance. Indeed, Zhang et al. [7] have explicitly studied high temperature performance in the case of additively-manufactured $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ while Mannan et al. [8] described and collated significant information relating to the corrosion resistance of several nickel super-alloys. As a result, In718 has multiple applications in the aerospace [9] and energy sectors [8]. Unfortunately, as explored by Thakur et al. [10], In718 remains difficult to machine via traditional, subtractive manufacturing processes. In contrast to subtractive manufacturing, additively-produced parts are built layer-wise. During L-PBF AM in particular, a laser beam is used to selectively melt a thin layer of metal powder in the shape of a crosssection of the desired final part. After each layer is fused, the build platform is lowered and a new layer of powder is deposited. The entire, layer-wise, process is typically referred to as a “build” and occurs within a build chamber purged with an inert gas.

Many of the most important melt pool-scale defects in metal AM can be identified by the ex-situ morphology of the melt tracks themselves.

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-4
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: In this work, morphologies of interest are those characteristic of process outcomes including porosity formed by the keyholing mechanism, under-melting, and the surface tension-related balling phenomenon. Cunningham et al. [11] provide a comprehensive overview of porosity formation, due to a variety of mechanisms, in Laser and Electron Beam PBF AM. Keyhole and under-melting porosity are further explored by Gong et al. [12] for the Ti-6Al-4V alloy. Gratzke et al. [13] provide an excellent theoretical basis for understanding balling during welding processes while Yadroitsev et al. [14] studied this phenomenon in LPBF specifically. Keyhole-mode melting occurs in the high energy density (high beam power, low beam velocity) region of process space, where significant vaporization of the molten material can occur. Under certain conditions, the resultant vapor pocket may become trapped as porosity in the solidified melt pool [12]. Under-melting occurs when the melt pool does not fully penetrate the powder layer [12]. Francis [3] has found that balling primarily occurs in the higher beam velocity and beam power regime of process space [3]. Specifically, as the melt pools lengthen relative to their widths, Rayleigh instabilities driven by surface tension forces cause the tail of the melt pool to first form “humps” and eventually cease to be a continuous melt track, instead breaking up into discrete “balls” as discussed by Yadroitsev et al. [14].

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-5
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: Importantly, these characteristic morphologies are known to occur with varying degrees of periodicity within a single melt track and the statistical behavior of these deviations are a central focus of this work. Such periodicity has been observed ex-situ in L-PBF by Olakanmi et al. [15] for an aluminum alloy. Recently, Zhao et al. [16] has observed much of this behavior in-situ via high speed X-ray imaging. Similarly, the geometry of the melt pool is generally accepted to vary along the length of a melt track, even when process parameters and local build geometry remain constant. Francis [3] and Wei et al. [17] have characterized the variable behavior of melt pool depth in keyhole-mode melting for L-PBF and GTAW welding respectively, and extensive research exists within the welding community on variability due to humping, as summarized by Wei [18]. Nonetheless, the existing literature is relatively sparse with regards to the statistical study of general melt pool variability in the AM processes. For this reason, this work constructs a statistically significant database of melt pool geometry and morphology for the $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ material system. In addition to providing insights into such variability, the presented results are also used by the authors in concurrent work to facilitate the training of a Machine Learning algorithm for in-situ flaw detection [19].

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-6
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: One method for correlating process parameters with process outcomes (e.g. melt pool geometry, porosity, and as-built microstructure) is known as “process mapping.” Developed by Beuth and Klingbeil [1], this technique is used in this work to summarize the effects of laser beam power and travel velocity on the size of the melt pools as well as to delineate certain defect regimes. While process mapping of L-PBFprocessed In718 has been reported by Narra [20], those data are based on single cross-sections of each process parameter combination – precluding the study of morphological and dimensional variability. Furthermore, as found by Aboulkhair et al. [21] for balling and Montgomery [22] for melt pool depth, melt pool morphology can vary significantly depending the presence of a powder layer (vs. no powder). Therefore the use of the no-added powder experiments performed by [20] would be inappropriate for the purposes of linking in-situ and exsitu observations during construction of a bulk part, which is the goal of the authors’ concurrent work [19].

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-7
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-8
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: The experiment was performed on an EOS M290 (EOS GmbH, Germany) L-PBF machine at Carnegie Mellon University’s (CMU) NextManufacturing Center and consisted of 10 melt tracks at each of 36 different process parameter combinations. The tested beam powers range between $1 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $3 7 0 W$ (the maximum power of the EOS M290 machine) and the beam travel velocities range between $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } /$ s and $1 4 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / s$ – spanning the majority of the EOS M290’s operating range. These parameter combinations are subsequently indicated in Fig. 7 and were chosen based on the Rosenthal analytical heat transfer model of a moving point heat source [23]. The Rosenthal model by no means fully describes the physics driving melt pool formation as it assumes steady-state conditions and a point heat source [3] as well as neglecting temperature-dependent material properties, the latent heat of fusion, and all non-conduction heat transfer mechanisms including fluid flow within the melt pool itself. However, when fit to experimental data1 it is sufficient to inform experiment design decisions. Specifically, the Rosenthal results were combined with the work of [20] and the balling threshold presented by Francis [3] to ensure that the test region of process space would include multiple instances of keyholing and balling anomalies. Additionally, the Rosenthal results allowed for the estimation of a maximum expected melt pool width $( 3 5 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and length $( 8 6 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ , thus enabling the determination of a conservative hatch spacing $( 5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ and melt track length $\mathsf { 2 0 } \mathrm { m m }$ . All of the melt tracks were exposed with a preheat temperature of $8 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and a nominal D86 beam diameter of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ .

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-9
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: The melt tracks were exposed on a 6 in $\times 6$ in $\times \ 0 . 2 5$ in $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ plate (Fig. 1a) sourced from McMaster-Carr (P/N: 1099N8). Each melt track is $2 0 \mathrm { m m }$ long to ensure steady-state2 melt pool conditions in the crosssectioned regions. The melt tracks were exposed on top of a single layer of powder as opposed to a bare substrate and were spaced sufficiently far apart $( 5 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ to avoid any overlap between adjacent melt pools. Due to the importance of a consistent powder layer for these experiments, denudation of the region around the melt track is also an important consideration. Work by Matthews et al. [24] finds that the denudation zone extends between $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and $2 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ from the center of the melt track for processing conditions similar to those explored in this work. Therefore the denudation zones of adjacent melt tracks are not expected to have influenced the observed melt pool morphologies. To mitigate the effects of residual heating due to adjacent melt tracks the exposure order of the melt tracks was adjusted such that a minimum of $_ { 1 . 6 s }$ elapsed between the lasing of adjacent melt tracks. For more information on residual heating due to laser scan strategy the authors refer the reader to the work of Parry et al. [25].

name: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive-part-10
fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
content: To maintain a consistent powder layer thickness for all of the melt tracks, the $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ plate was first mounted to a modified steel EOS build plate and then surface ground. Because the In718 plate had to be removed from the modified steel EOS build plate before being placed inside of the EOS M290, their relative orientations during surface grinding were recorded. Note that layer-wise post-fusion consolidation, described by Jacob et al. [26], of the metal powder results in an effective powder layer thickness that is greater than the thickness of the layers within the AM part (i.e. the nominal layer thickness). To better match the nominal $4 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ thick layers used in the authors’ concurrent work [19], a $7 0 \mu \mathrm { m } \pm 2 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ thick powder layer was chosen. This choice was made assuming a consolidation factor $( 1 - \rho _ { p o w d e r } / \rho _ { f u s e d } )$ of $4 0 \%$ [26]. Note that the true consolidation percentage is dependent upon the particle size distribution of the specific powder system used; however such a measurement is beyond the scope of this work. The uncertainty in powder layer thickness was quantified by measuring the change in the separation distance between recoater blade and the build plate over the entire area of the $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ build plate; relative gap measurements were performed using a Käfer dial depth gauge. Systematic error in the powder layer thickness is assumed to be minimal (less than $1 0 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ as a result of the procedure used to determine the gap between the recoater blade and the $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ plate. During this procedure, after leveling of the plate with the profilometer was complete, the gap was systematically decreased in increments of $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ until the recoater blade was unable to travel across the $\mathrm { I n 7 1 8 }$ plate.

fileName: 2019 - AM - Scime, Beuth - Melt pool geometry and morphology variability for the Inconel 718 alloy in a laser powder bed fusion additive.md
