Fig. 11 Pore volume and pore number from constant LEDs of a $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ and b $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$

![](images/c6e44e819e6e8f6b7909090a680ea6f438462590a502f9a1de8319f9257f30ab.jpg)  
Fig. 12 Transverse melt pool boundary obtained from LED $=$ $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ single tracks

Figure 12 clearly shows that the melt pool characteristic is not the function of the linear energy density. As the melt pool depth depends on the power, speed, and the material properties, the normalized enthalpy is used for better representation. The calibrated normalized enthalpy obtained by [8], which is shown in eq. 2, is used,

$$
{ \frac { \Delta H } { h _ { \mathrm { s } } } } = { \frac { A P } { \pi h _ { \mathrm { s } } { \sqrt { D u \sigma ^ { 3 } } } } }
$$

where $\Delta H$ is the specific enthalpy, $h _ { \mathrm { s } }$ is the enthalpy at melting, $A$ is the absorptivity, $P$ is the laser power, $D$ is the thermal diffusivity, $u$ is the laser speed, and $\sigma$ is the Gaussian beam size. The melt pool depth is the function of normalized enthalpy; therefore, normalized depth may be written as

$$
\mathrm { N o r m a l i z e d \ d e p t h } = f n \biggl ( { \frac { A P } { \pi h _ { \mathrm { s } } \sqrt { D u \sigma ^ { 3 } } } } \biggr ) .
$$

The dimensionless depth normalized to the Gaussian beam size is plotted against the normalized enthalpy as shown in Fig. 13. As the depth to half-width ratio is used to distinguish the keyhole melting and the conduction melting, it is also included in Fig. 13. Generally, the normalized depth and the depth to half-width ratio increased with increasing enthalpy. However, there are certain cases where higher enthalpy resulted in lower depths.

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-22
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The transverse depth is used to assess the effect of enthalpy on the depth. However, it is important to note that the depth would change along the longitudinal direction and the melt pool profile taken at a single transverse direction may sometimes lead to dubious comparisons. Hence, a longitudinal melt profile is obtained through metallography. Figure 14 presents the two examples of the longitudinal melt pool boundaries obtained with $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ (120 W, $2 5 0 ~ \mathrm { m m / s }$ , and $1 4 4 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ , $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s } )$ , and two with $0 . 7 5 \ \mathrm { J / m m } \ ( 1 3 1 \ \mathrm { W } , 1 7 5 \ \mathrm { m m / s }$ and 150 W, $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ ). The variation in the depth along the scan direction is evident from the longitudinal melt pool boundary. Moreover, the depth of the melt pool for 144 W is higher than that of $1 2 0 \mathrm { W }$ . The depth measured from the transverse profile is $1 0 8 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , and the range of the depth measured from the longitudinal profile is $8 8 ~  { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ to $1 7 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . The depth of the transverse melt pool would, therefore, change according to the location. The range of the depths obtained for different cases is included as an error bar in Fig. 13. The longitudinal profiles of single tracks formed with $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ show that the keyhole pores are more frequent near the bottom of the melt pool.

![](images/5aafdaed443555e5affcd59506187ae9d4ab736b1d62bf641c90a498bf6de919.jpg)  
Fig. 13 The effect of normalized enthalpy on the non-dimensional depth and depth to width ratio

![](images/8ba47369f8d8ee934cf4ec5d1282dd0fa4fe3d6dc16429c404e9843a53865995.jpg)  
Fig. 14 Longitudinal melt profile obtained from $\mathrm { L E D } = 0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ and $0 . 7 5 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ single tracks

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-23
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The depth to width ratio shows that the conduction mode melting occurred up to $9 6 \mathrm { W }$ laser power and $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m / s }$ scan speed, which corresponded to the normalized enthalpy of 5.5. As the power and speed increased to $1 2 0 \mathrm { W }$ and $2 5 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ , the depth to half-width ratio became greater than 1, suggesting a formation of a keyhole for which the corresponding enthalpy is around 6. In this case, the transition from the conduction to the keyhole mode melting is observed to be around $\Delta H / h _ { \mathrm { s } } { = } 6$ . Two lines are drawn to distinguish the keyhole modes based on the normalized depth and the depth to width ratios. The horizontal line is drawn for a depth ratio of 1, which would separate the keyhole parameters based on the depth to halfwidth ratio. The vertical line separates the keyhole parameters based on the normalized enthalpy. The use of enthalpy as a design parameter is, therefore, a simple approach to identify the process parameters as the keyhole or the conduction parameters. The frequency of the pore formation is lower for $1 3 1 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ , hence resulted in the fewer pore number compared to the 150 W power.

As the power has more effect on the depth than the speed, it is expected to have differences in the depth with the change in the level of power and speed, even if the LED is kept constant. Besides, laser power has more effect on the peak temperature of the melt pool during the SLM process, and the temperature increases with an increase in power. Numerical models may be used to predict the real-time temperature and flow of the melt pool, which determines the shape of the melt pool boundary. Hence, a micro-scale numerical model is developed to predict the melt pool formation with different levels of power and speed.

content:
Figure 15 presents the temperature contour along the longitudinal direction when the laser has traveled $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , $1 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , $2 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , and $2 5 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . At low power (48 W and $7 2 \mathrm { ~ W ~ } ,$ , the melting occurs purely by conduction. The heat absorbed by the free surface exposed to the laser is diffused to the substrate, which melts the material beneath, forming a shallow melt pool. The temperature profile shows that the temperature is higher than the boiling temperature for some region; however, the vaporization is not enough to generate the substantial vapor pressure to form a depression. The melt pool formed by the pure conduction is very shallow, with the depth to width ratio being well below 1. For the laser power of $9 2 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ , a depression is formed, leading to a deeper melt pool. However, it is not regarded as the keyhole mode melting in this study as the depth to half-width ratio about 1. The vapor opening has a larger diameter and remains open all the time; hence, the possibility of the pore formation due to the collapse of the vapor opening is minimal. When the power is increased to $1 2 0 \mathrm { W }$ , the region with a temperature greater than the evaporation temperature is very high, and the material evaporation exerts the recoil pressure forming a keyhole. Hence, the shape of the transverse profile is determined by the shape of the keyhole. As the temperature passes the boiling temperature, there is a significant increase in the recoil pressure, due to the exponential relationship [20]:

$$
P _ { \mathrm { r e c o i l } } = 0 . 5 4 P _ { \mathrm { 0 } } \mathrm { e x p } \left( \frac { \varDelta H _ { \mathrm { v } } \left( T - T _ { \mathrm { v } } \right) } { R T T _ { \mathrm { v } } } \right)
$$

content: The melting modes in the SLM process depend on the laser parameters. Hence, the effect of LED on the melting modes and keyhole porosity is investigated in this study. EOS M270 is used to fabricate Inconel 625 single tracks with different levels of LEDs. The pores formed inside the single tracks were analyzed using a CT scanner, and metallography was conducted to obtain the transverse melt profile. Besides, the variation in the melt pool geometry with different combinations of laser power and scan speed resulting in the same LED is investigated. The conclusions are summarized as follows:

name: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In-part-27
fileName: 2021 - Int. J. Advanced Manufacturing Technology - Shrestha, Chou - An investigation into melting modes in selective laser melting of In.md
content:
The mode of melting progressed from conduction to keyhole with increasing LED. The depth of the keyhole and the porosity mostly increased with increasing energy density. However, the maximum porosity was obtained at $0 . 9 0 \ \mathrm { J / m m }$ (180 W, $2 0 0 \ \mathrm { m m / s }$ ) instead of the highest LED investigated, i.e., $0 . 9 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ obtained with $1 9 5 \mathrm { ~ W ~ }$ , $2 0 0 \mathrm { m m } / \mathrm { s }$ . & The melt pool boundaries obtained from the $0 . 4 8 ~ \mathrm { J / m m }$ LED parameters show that the depth of the melt pool increased consistently with the increase in laser power. The level of power determines the mode of melting for the same LED. However, the keyhole porosity did not increase with an increase in the melt pool depth, instead, the keyhole porosity increased to a certain level and then decreased with further increase in laser power. & The numerical results show that the increase in the melt pool depth is due to the increase in the melt pool temperature and the vapor pressure. There is a significant increase in penetration with a small increase in laser power due to the exponential relationship between the recoil pressure and the surface temperature. The vapor opening in the conduction mode is stable, and the instability in the keyhole becomes evident with an increase in the depth of the keyhole. LED may not be used as a sole parameter to distinguish the mode of melting as the laser power has a greater effect on melt pool depth than the scan speed. Normalized enthalpy, which includes process parameters as well as material properties, may be more appropriate to explain the shifting from conduction to keyhole mode melting.

Acknowledgements Sabina Chertmanova assisted with CT scanning and reconstruction of tested samples.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-1
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
# Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys: A High-throughput physics-informed and data-enabled approach
Brent Vela a,∗ , Seth Mehalic a , Sofia Sheikh a , Alaa Elwany a,c , Ibrahim Karaman a,b , Raymundo Arróyave a,b,c

a Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA b Department of Mechanical Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA c Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX 77843, USA

# a r t i c l e i n f o


# a b s t r a c t
Keywords:   
Additive manufacturing   
Alloy design   
CALPHAD   
Melting   
Balling

To date, the vast majority of work on metal additive manufacturing (AM) has been framed in terms of the need to tune processing conditions for a particular AM technology in order to print conventional alloys, oftentimes developed for fabrication methods other than AM. This approach overlooks the fact that historically, many engineering alloy system has been designed with a particular processing route in mind, e.g., ingot metallurgy, powder metallurgy, rapid quenching, etc. There are thus significant opportunities to design alloys specifically for AM. A key challenge is that alloy design requires performance metrics that can be optimized by exploring the alloy chemistry space. Here, we present a study in which we examine how intrinsic thermophysical properties can be used to estimate performance metrics related to the behavior of a solidifying metal droplet under AM-relevant conditions. By identifying these intrinsic properties, it is possible to directly incorporate ‘intrinsic printability’, specifically ‘intrinsic resistance to balling’, into AM-focused alloy design.
summary: a b s t r a c t, a r t i c l e i n f o, Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys: A High-throughput physics-informed and data-enabled approach

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-2
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
The design of alloys for powder bed fusion (PBF) additive manufacturing (AM) must be informed of the processing conditions that the specimen will be subjected to [1]. During PBF AM, alloys are exposed to large thermal gradients, complex thermal history, and rapid solidification conditions [2]. These processing conditions often result in printed parts with microstructures, properties, and performance that differ from specimens processed with conventional methods [3]. If processing parameters are not compatible with a particular alloy, the AMmanufactured artifact may experience several processing induced complications and defects such as residual internal stresses (leading to distortions and cracking), nonuniform melting and solidification (leading to hot tearing/cracking), vaporization of alloying components (leading to undesired stoichiometry in the alloy), unintentional trapping of gases within the solidifying alloy (i.e., keyholing), or incomplete wetting and spreading (leading to incomplete fusion of layers and balling) [3,4].

Two solutions have been proposed to remedy these complications: develop strategies to modify conventional alloys to be more amenable to AM and/or develop novel alloys using metrics for intrinsic printability as design constraints [3]. To date, the majority of research into metal AM has been framed in terms of the former solution. However, there remain significant opportunities to design alloys specifically for AM.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-3
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
In the case of alloy design, the high cost of powder fabrication for AM severely restricts the experimental search for intrinsically printable alloys in an iterative manner. Prior knowledge of these alloys, captured in the form of printability indicators, must be leveraged to intelligently search for printable alloys across vast composition spaces. These printability indicators can be based on extrinsic factors, such as processing parameters, or intrinsic factors inherent to the alloy in question, such as solidification range and thermal diffusivity [5,6].

Research into the amenability of an alloy to AM has focused on combinations of extrinsic factors such as laser power, beam diameter, scan speed, or linear energy density (LED), defined as the laser power divided by the scan speed $( P / v )$ [7–11]. However, in recent years, more work has been done on identifying indicators for intrinsic printability. Of particular relevance to this work, Zhou et al. demonstrated that the balling phenomenon is a process in which the spreading and solidification of the alloy melt compete with each other, where the spreading and solidification behavior are determined by the intrinsic properties of the metal [12].

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-4
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: In this work, we further develop this notion, demonstrating a CALPHAD-based metric of intrinsic resistance to balling defined as the ratio between the characteristic solidification and spreading times, $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ can be used as an optimizable indicator of balling within alloy design schemes. Specifically, in Section 3 we perform CALPHAD calculations to estimate $\tau _ { \mathrm { s o l i d } } / \tau _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d } }$ across three exemplary ternary alloy systems, identifying regions in the ternary alloy space that are predicted to be resistant to balling as an exercise in alloy design for AM. In Section 4 we benchmark the proposed indicator against experimental data by accomplishing the following: We show that the proposed criterion is correlated with the size of the processing-parameter window with which an alloy can be printed without exhibiting balling; and we exploit said correlation by using the indicator as an informative feature in a machine-learning model that, given two simple features that capture laser parameters, is able to predict the probability of a balling with reasonable accuracy.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-5
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: Printability indicators are properties that can screen for printable alloys in a high-throughput (HTP) manner. Mukherjee et al. [13] developed indicators based on both intrinsic alloy properties and PBF processing parameters. The authors related alloy properties to indicators for dimensional inaccuracy in printed parts, composition change due to vaporization of alloying components, and lack of fusion defects [13]. The Scheil-Gulliver curve and solidification range have been used as indicators of hot tearing, hot cracking, and compositional microsegregation; a wide solidification range has been shown to increase the chance of hot tearing and leads to greater compositional microsegregation during solidification [3,14–16]. Kou developed an indicator for hot cracking susceptibility based on the Scheil-Gulliver curve (i.e. temperature vs. solid fraction), where the derivative of temperature with respect to the square root of the solid fraction, $| d T / d ( f _ { S } ) ^ { 1 / 2 } |$ , corresponds to greater susceptibility to hot cracking [17]. A similar indicator, developed by Easton et al., is defined by the integral of the Scheil-Gulliver curve with respect to temperature from the coherency temperature (where liquid feeding is restricted) to the coalescence temperature (where a network of solid is formed), $\int _ { T _ { o } } ^ { T _ { c o } } f _ { S } d T$ [18]. Recently, Du et al. have proposed a machine learning (ML) enabled balling susceptibility index based on 6 following mechanistic variables: volumetric energy density, Richardson number, pool aspect ratio, surface tension force, surface tension force, and solidification time [19]. These results rely on a ML-model trained on 166 experimental observations of PBF that capture the aforementioned mechanistic variables [19], whereas in this work we present a CALPHAD-based approach to determining intrinsic resistance to balling.

content: Moreover, we use a large experimental dataset consisting of 2496 observations of dwell time, LED, and the proposed balling indicator to train a probabilistic classifier for balling during PBF.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-7
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: An analysis of the balling mechanism by Zhou et al. [12] revealed that during selective laser melting (SLM) of tungsten, the tendency for balling could be predicted by a simplified model in which melt spreading and solidification compete. When alloys solidify quickly and spread slowly, balling is more likely, as in the case of tungsten [12]. When alloys remain molten longer and spread quickly, balling is less likely, as in the case of titanium [12]. This simplified model has been used by Guo et al. [20] to explain balling in IN738LC superalloy. During 25 single track PBF experiments on IN738LC, balling was observed in 9 tracks; The estimated characteristic solidification time was less than the estimated spreading time for these 9 tracks whereas all continuous tracks had estimated spreading times less than the estimated solidification time. Likewise Liu et al. used the same simplified model to explain to explain balling resistance during PBF of AZ61 magnesium alloy [21]. The authors rank ordered AZ61 among several metals based on their their predicted resistance to balling, obtaining the following: $\mathrm { T i } > \mathrm { N i } >$ $\mathbf { F e } > \mathbf { A Z 6 } 1 > \mathbf { M g } > \mathbf { C u } .$ . The authors noted that if superheat is added to the melt pool the solidification time will increase relative to the spreading time and balling can be mitigated in AZ61. Despite this, Zhou’s model has yet to be used in HTP forward prediction of balling resistance.
summary: 3. High throughput calculation of characteristic spreading and solidification times - Part 1/8

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-8
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: This model is based on several assumptions, stated below. Building on the work of Schiaffino and Sonin [22], Zhou et al. [12] considered the case where a molten tungsten (W) droplet, with radius $a$ and temperature $T _ { o } ,$ is formed on a subcooled (held at $T _ { a }$ ) substrate of the same material as the droplet. Assuming isothermal deposition and spreading, the spherical droplet at time $t = 0$ will begin to wet the substrate while simultaneously solidifying. In the simplified case of homologous wetting on a flat surface where both solidification and oxidation are neglected, droplet spreading is characterized by the Weber number, and the Ohnesorge number, ???? = ?????? 2?? and $\begin{array} { r } { Z = \frac { \mu } { \sqrt { \rho \sigma a } } } \end{array}$ respectively. Density is denoted by $\rho _ { m }$ , whereas $\sigma$ represents surface tension, $\mu$ represents viscosity, $V$ is impact velocity, and $a$ is the radius of the molten droplet, which is assumed to be initially spherical [22,23]. During PBF, molten droplets are approximately $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ [12], meaning gravitational effects, captured by the Bond number, $\frac { \rho g a ^ { 3 } } { \sigma }$ are negligible as $a$ is small [22,23]. Additionally, during PBF droplets are sessile, meaning $W _ { e }$ would be $\sim 0$ since $V = 0$ . For molten metals $Z$ is extremely small [12]. Low $W _ { e }$ and $Z$ indicate spreading is primarily driven by capillary flow [12].
summary: 3. High throughput calculation of characteristic spreading and solidification times - Part 2/8

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-9
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: The melt spreading and solidification timescales are determined by intrinsic alloy properties and laser processing parameters. The thermal timescales associated with the solidification of an alloy droplet, defined by Schiaffino and Sonin [22], 23], are split into two regimes, $\tau _ { 1 }$ and $\tau _ { 2 }$ . The first timescale, Eq. (1), represents the time required to remove superheat from the droplet, bringing it to its fusion temperature. The fusion temperature is assumed to be distinct [22,23], and is taken to be the solidus temperature in this work. The second timescale, Eq. (2), provides the time for the droplet to remove latent heat of fusion and solidify, where $a$ is the initial droplet radius, $\alpha$ is thermal diffusivity, $k _ { a }$ is the thermal conductivity of the alloy at ambient temperature, $k$ is thermal conductivity at liquidus, $L$ is latent heat, $C$ is heat capacity, $T _ { f }$ and $T _ { 0 }$ are fusion (solidus) temperature and initial temperature, respectively [22,23]. In this work, $T _ { 0 }$ is defined as the liquidus, such that no superheat is added to the molten droplet. Ambient temperature, $T _ { a : }$ , is defined as $2 9 8 \mathrm { K } ,$ approximating conditions for a single track experiment with no preheating and no previously printed layers. Characteristic timescales for solidification and spreading can be extracted from such a simulation. Following the convention of Zhou et al. the initial droplet radius are defined as $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , common for SLM processing [12]. Both timescales rely on the simplification that heat exits the droplet by conduction via the underlying substrate. Eq. (3) predicts total solidification time, relating Eqs. (1) and (2). The timescale associated with the spreading of an alloy droplet can be estimated by Eq. (4), where $\rho$ is the melt density, $a$ is initial droplet radius, and $\sigma$ is the surface tension of the liquid [22,23].
summary: 3. High throughput calculation of characteristic spreading and solidification times - Part 3/8

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-11
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
To develop a framework to utilize $\tau _ { \mathrm { s o l i d } } / \tau _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d } }$ as a printability indicator, we used Thermo-Calc TCAL7, TCHEA5, and TCNI11 thermodynamic databases and their corresponding property models to predict the properties required to compute $\tau _ { \mathrm { s o l i d } } / \tau _ { \mathrm { s p r e a d } }$ for the Ti-Al-V, Ta-NbW, and Fe-Cr-Ni ternaries, respectively. We consider the Ti-Al-V ternary as it contains Ti-6Al-4V, an alloy commonly used in AM. We consider the Nb-Ta-W system as an exemplary refractory system. Additionally, we consider the Fe-Ni-Cr system as it is the basis of Ni-based superalloys and stainless steels. The alloy systems are uniformly grid sampled varying the alloy composition by $2 \mathrm { a t . \% }$ considering unary, binary, and ternary compositions. A total of 1326 alloys comprise each system, thoroughly sampling the ternary diagrams in Fig. 1. An thermodynamic-equilibrium simulation is used to predict the solidus $( T _ { f } )$ and liquidus $\left( T _ { o } \right)$ temperatures for each alloy in a HTP manner. A Scheil solidification simulation is used to predict the latent heat of fusion, $L$ . An equilibrium property model is used to predict melt density $( \rho )$ , heat capacity $( C )$ , thermal conductivity at liquidus $( k )$ and ambient temperatures $( k _ { a } )$ , thermal diffusivity $( \alpha )$ , and surface tension $( \sigma )$ .

![](images/1812051f2867c50a2cdc7586ed6972889401cfa7b85b3813a769cdd30d554a66.jpg)  
Fig. 1. Ternary contour plots for Ti-Al-V, Nb-Ta-W, and Fe-Ni-Cr systems, plotting $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ over ternary composition map to be used as an indicator for compositions that will likely exhibit balling during AM processes.
summary: 3. High throughput calculation of characteristic spreading and solidification times - Part 5/8

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-12
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
The $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ ratio can be used as an optimizable balling indicator, where a larger value of $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ indicates a lesser likelihood for an alloy to exhibit balling during AM processing, indicated as green regions in Fig. 1. In the case of the Nb-Ta-W ternary, the intrinsic properties of tungsten make it difficult to print [12]. This is demonstrated in Fig. 1, where $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ is minimized (indicating susceptibility to balling) for compositions of Nb-Ta-W with greater W $\mathbf { a t \% }$ , however, by increasing the Nb content, the alloys within this ternary could be designed to be more amenable to AM. In fact, Nb has been shown experimentally to be much more ‘printable’ than W [24,25].

In a similar design exercise, we consider Inconel 718, a Fe-Ni-Cr based superalloy containing $\mathbf { F e } _ { 1 8 . 6 } \mathbf { N i } _ { 5 3 . 2 } \mathbf { C r } _ { 2 0 . 7 }$ $\left( \mathsf { a t } \% \right)$ and ${ < } 7 . 5 \ \mathrm { a t } \%$ minor alloying additions [26]. Fig. 1 suggests Inconel 718 would likely not exhibit balling, in agreement with its amenability to AM previously proven by applications in industry. However, 316 stainless steel, containing $\mathbf { F e } _ { 6 5 . 0 } \mathbf { N i } _ { 1 1 . 9 } \mathbf { C r } _ { 1 8 . 7 }$ $( \mathsf { a t } \% )$ and $< 4 . 4 \ \mathrm { a t \% }$ of minor alloying additions, has a $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d } < 4$ , indicating susceptibility to balling. This is in agreement with studies on the AM of 316 stainless steel, where balling was indeed observed [27]. Likewise, within the Ti-Al-V ternary alloy system, Ti-6Al-4V, a commonly additively manufactured engineering alloy [7,28–30], falls in a printable region within the composition space, near $9 0 \ \mathrm { a t . } \%$ Ti, again, demonstrating the utility of the proposed indicator in alloy design.
summary: 3. High throughput calculation of characteristic spreading and solidification times - Part 6/8

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-13
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
The proposed metric can rank the resistance to balling of various alloys. In Table 1, several compositions and their $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ values are displayed. Metals with high thermal diffusivity and surface tension, such as W, are ranked lower than alloys that spread much quicker than they solidify, such as Ti-rich alloys like NiTi and Ti-6Al-4V. In general, pure elements have less favorable $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ ratios than alloys. This is mostly due to the fact that increased alloy complexity leads to lowering of thermal conductivity due to enhanced (phonon and electron) scattering. In agreement with this assertion, the high entropy Cantor alloy family has a favorable $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ ratio, comparable to those of alloys that experiments have suggested are relatively easy to print. These results suggest that there are opportunities to discover high entropy alloys that, in addition to meeting or exceeding performance requirements, are also printable. name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-14
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: Radiative heat effects were considered but were determined to be negligible. As an example, a pure W droplet with $1 0 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ radius superheated to $4 0 0 0 \mathrm { K }$ requires approximately $4 { - } 1 0 ^ { - 6 } s$ to solidify via conduction and approximately $5 . 4 1 \mathrm { - } 1 0 ^ { - 3 }$ s to solidify by radiation, indicating that conduction is the dominant heat transfer mode by an approximate factor of $\sim 4 0$ —when considering cooling to room temperature, conduction is ${ \sim } 1 8 0 { , } 0 0 0$ faster since radiative heat transfer decays as $T ^ { 4 }$ , while conduction is linear in $T$ .
summary: 3. High throughput calculation of characteristic spreading and solidification times - Part 8/8

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-15
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
The indicator alone cannot predict whether or not an alloy will exhibit balling, but instead can only rank alloys according to their intrinsic resistance to balling. In order to make such a prediction, PBF processing parameters must also be defined. To benchmark the predictive ability of the indicator against experimental data, we first demonstrate how $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ is indeed correlated with the size of the processingparameter window with which an alloy can be printed without exhibiting balling. We then exploit this correlation by leveraging $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ as a feature in various machine-learning models to predict the probability of balling.

Alloy compositions, laser processing parameters, and an experimentally determined binary classification for balling were gathered from an in-house database focused on the AM of alloys. The data is a combination of experimental results published in literature and experiments conducted in-house at Texas A&M University. A subset of the database (alloys assessed in Thermo-Calc TCHEA5, TINI11, and TCAL7 databases), comprised of 2527 unique alloy-process observations and 158 unique compositions, was used to conduct the experimental validation of the indicator. Specifically, these 2527 observations are PBF experiments using pre-alloyed powders. The experiments were performed on various machines with different printing environments, initial powder bed temperatures, powder particle size distributions, atmospheres, and build geometries; The following work does not account for these factors as they are not well populated in the database. The alloys represented in the database spanned over 11 material systems including stainless steels, aluminum-based alloys, nickel-based alloys, and high entropy alloys [12,27,31–121]. A redacted version of the database is available in the Code Ocean capsule associated with this work.

Each violin plot shows the compositional distribution of all elements within the database and the frequency at which balling occurs when elements are present at various compositions. b) The relative amount of every element contained within the database. c) A UMAP projection of the database. Clusters of alloy systems are labeled in italics while clusters of specific alloys are not. d) The proposed criteria plotted against both processing parameters.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-17
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: Fig. 2 depicts various visualizations of the database. Fig. 2a shows the frequency at which various elements appear in the database at various compositions. This frequency is depicted with split violin plots where the red distributions correspond to experiments that resulted in balling and green distributions correspond to experiments that did not. From such a visualization one could conclude there are no alloys within the database that contain between $2 0 \mathrm { w t . } \%$ and $4 0 \mathrm { w t . } \%$ Al, rather, if Al is present in an alloy it is present below $2 0 \mathrm { w t . } \%$ , between $4 0 \mathrm { w t . } \%$ and $6 0 \mathrm { w t . } \%$ or at $8 0 \mathrm { w t . } \%$ and above. Fig. 2b depicts the relative amounts of elements present in the database. The database is chiefly rich in Ni, Ti, and Al. Fig. 2c depicts a uniform manifold Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP). UMAP is a non-linear dimensionality reduction technique [122]. In this UMAP projection alloys that are compositionally similar are plotted closer to each other in the 2D projection. This results in clusters of alloys and alloy systems. Alloy systems (clusters not containing a single alloy) are labeled in italics while clusters of specific alloys are not. The dwell time and the LED were selected as features as these are simple and readily available processing parameters that encode the amount of heat added to the powder. Volumetric energy density was considered as a feature however was not selected as it was not as well populated in the database as the LED. Fig. 2d depicts the proposed indicator plotted against the processing parameters in the database; These plots visualize how the frequency of balling changes with $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ and laser parameters. A large LED and a long dwell time prevents balling as there is sufficient heat added to the melt pool such that it can spread before solidifying.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-18
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
As $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ increases, balling occurs at lower values of LED and shorter dwell times, increasing the processing window, as seen in Fig. 2d. This concept of the ‘processing window’ is illustrated in the Supplementary Materials associated with this work. This trend is present in 2496 experimental observation despite only accounting for composition (encoded by $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d } )$ and the LED and dwell time. This is an indication that $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ is indeed correlated to the occurrence of balling in PBF-AM.

Table 2 Performance metrics resulting from 5-fold cross validation of three classifiers trained on $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , dwell time, and LED values.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-20
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: To predict balling within the alloy-processing parameter space, the alloy space is encoded by $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ and the processing parameter space is encoded by LED and dwell time. Using $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , laser dwell time, and LED as features, common Scikit-Learn [123] classifiers were trained: Adaptive-Boosting model (referred to as AdaBoost) [124], Multi-layer Perceptron classifier (referred to as Neural Network) [125] and Gaussian Process classifier [126]. A 5-fold cross-validation was performed to avoid biases while benchmarking the classification models. In each training fold features were standardized prior to training. Of the 2496 observed alloy-processing parameter pairs, 321 resulted in balling while 2175 did not. To address this class imbalance, the minority class was over-sampled via the creation of synthetic examples in a data-operation known as synthetic minority over-sampling technique (SMOTE) [127]. Plausible synthetic samples are created by considering each minority class entry and introducing synthetic entries along line segments connecting the k-nearest neighbors of the minority class in the feature space [127]. In addition to over-sampling the minority class, the majority class was randomly under-sampled, by recommendation of the authors of SMOTE [127]. SMOTE was applied during cross validation to all training folds while the test fold was left unaltered, ensuring no data-leakage between folds. In the context of this work, SMOTE results in the creation of synthetic balling entries with LED and dwell time values that are similar to entries that were observed to exhibit balling in reality. These data-operations resulted in a training set initially consisting of 270 balling entries and 1708 non-balling entries to contain 854 balling entries and 1708 non balling entries.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-21
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: To evaluate classifier performance, the area-under-curve (AUC) score, which describes the probability that a given classifier will rank a randomly chosen positive instance higher than a randomly chosen negative instance [128], was calculated. In the case of this work, the AUC score indicates the probability that a classifier would assign a higher probability of balling to a randomly selected alloy-process parameter pair that exhibits balling than a randomly selected alloyprocess parameter pair that does not exhibit balling. To quantify the instances of false positives (FP), false negatives (FN), true positives (TP), and true negatives (TN) in the classifier predictions, precision, recall, and accuracy metrics were calculated. Precision, defined as, $P = T P / ( T P + F P )$ , captures the ability of the classifier to not label balling-resistant alloy-process pairs as balling-susceptible. Recall is defined as $R = ( T P ) / ( T P + F N )$ and captures the ability of the classifier to identify balling-susceptible alloy-process pairs. Accuracy is the fraction of correctly classified entries, mathematically defined as $A = ( T P +$ $T N ) / ( T P + T N + F P + F N )$ . The performance of these three classifiers trained on $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , LED, and dwell time values are summarized in Table 2. The hyperparameters of all classifiers were tuned in order to maximize the accuracy: The Neural Network classifiers had 3012 hidden layers; The Gaussian Process classifier had a Matern kernel with parameters of covarience $l = 3 . 8 4$ and $\nu = 0 . 0 1$ ; AdaBoost classifier had a maximum number of estimators set at 2863.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-22
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: None of the classifiers have acceptable precision, recall or AUC scores. This is likely due to the fact that there are no regions in the feature space $( \tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , LED, and dwell time) where balling is exclusively observed. There are only two types of regions within this feature space: regions free of balling observation and regions where balling is observed near non-balling observations. Therefore it is difficult to correctly predict balling within this feature space using ‘all or nothing’ decision boundaries.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-23
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: Probabilistic classification is better suited to such situations where both classes appear in overlapping regions within the feature space. Regions ‘richer’ in balling observations will be classified with a higher probability of exhibiting balling than those that are ‘lean’ in balling observations. Moreover, the probability of failure is more natural to use in risk analysis than sharp ‘all or nothing’ decision boundaries. Additionally, with probabilities of balling, prediction uncertainty can be gauged and used to determine where to sample additional data to refine the classifier (i.e. increase sampling where the probability of balling is predicted to be near 0.5). As such, the classifiers in this work perform much better when benchmarked against probabilistic metrics.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-24
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: Such a probabilistic classification metric is the Brier loss score, which is defined as $\begin{array} { r } { \frac { 1 } { N } \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { N } ( p _ { i } - o _ { i } ) ^ { 2 } } \end{array}$ where for N entries, $p _ { i }$ is the predicted probability of an event and $o _ { i }$ is 0 or 1 depending on if the event happened or not [129]. A perfect probabilistic classifier would have a Brier loss score of 0 while a completely inaccurate probabilistic classifier would have a Brier loss score of 1 [129]. Furthermore, the logloss score is often used to benchmark the performance of probabilistic models [130]. The log-loss score, defined as 1?? ∑????=1 −(???? log(????) + (1 − $y _ { i } ) \log ( 1 - p _ { i } )$ , is used to determine the similarity between distributions [130]. For each entry, ${ \bf y } _ { i }$ is the actual value and $\mathbf { p } _ { i }$ is the predicted probability. A log-loss of 0 indicates a perfectly calibrated probabilistic model whereas a score tending toward infinity indicates a poorly calibrated model [130]. The hyperparameters of all classifiers were tuned in order to minimize the log-loss score: The Neural Network classifier had 2275 hidden layers; The Guassian Process classifier had a Metern kernel with a parameters of covarience $l = 2 2 9 3$ and $\nu = 1 0 ;$ ; AdaBoost classifier had a maximum number of estimators set at 2932. The probabilistic results are summarized in Table 3.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-25
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
Motivated by the desire that outputted probabilities of balling are reflective of the actual probabilities of balling, the classifier in question must be well-calibrated [131]. A well-calibrated classifier returns class membership probabilities that are similar to the actual probability that a given sample would belong to the class in question [131]. In the context of this work, for a well-calibrated model that returns a $2 0 \%$ probability that a alloy-processing parameter pair will exhibit balling, 1 of 5 pairs with similar $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , dwell time, and LED values would actually exhibit balling.

![](images/66eeffe0f2b034516a6de2ab92d3b353eefe5cd9b77366cffb55a845e4ad7054.jpg)  
Fig. 3. Printability maps showing expected balling in red and no-expected balling in green. The printability maps show the effect of the alloy composition, encoded by the intrinsic printability metric, and the laser scan speed, encoded by LED, on printability. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-26
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: It is known that AdaBoost predicts distorted class membership probabilities [132]; This is attributed to the fact that boosting can be considered as an additive logistic regression model [132]. As a result, a boosting-model will attempt to replicate a logit of the true probabilities instead of the true probabilities [132], meaning AdaBoost models are typically poorly calibrated. To predict the actual probabilities, the logit transformation must be inverted, which can be achieved via isotonic regression [132]. A calibration curve can be used to gauge the how well a model is calibrated [131]. In a calibration curve, the predicted probabilities are binned and plotted along the $x$ -axis while the normalized frequency of observation is plotted on the $y \cdot$ -axis such that a perfectly calibrated model will have a calibration curve of the form $y = x ,$ , as shown in Fig. 3. The three classifiers were trained and calibrated with $7 5 \%$ of the database. For each test fold, 4 folds are used to train the classifier and the remaining fold is used to calibrate the trained model. These 5 models are then ensembled and provide an averaged probabilistic prediction. The remaining $2 5 \%$ of the database was considered a validation set and was used to generate the calibration curves in order to benchmark the calibrated models. Additional details about the training and testing data set can be found in the Supplementary Materials associated with this work. The calibration curves of the three classifiers are shown in Fig. 3. The Calibrated AdaBoost classifier is the best performing model after calibration.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-28
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content: As a final design exercise, the outputted probabilities of balling from the calibrated AdaBoost classifier were investigated within the Ti-AlV system, shown in Fig. 4. In general, within the Ti-Al-V ternary, the probability of balling increases for compositions with low $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ values (red region in Fig. 1a) as LED decreases, which makes intuitive sense: lower LED correspond to higher scan speeds (at a given power), which should increase the susceptibility to unstable melt pools. The calibration curve, Brier loss score, and log-loss score indicate acceptable performance by the classifier.

name: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e-part-29
fileName: 2022 - AM Letters - Vela et al. - Evaluating the intrinsic resistance to balling of alloys A High-throughput physics-informed and data-e.md
content:
# 5. Summary and conclusions
If an alloy-AM processing parameter pair are not compatible, the resulting specimen will exhibit processing induced complications such as residual internal stresses, nonuniform melting and solidification, balling, etc. Two solutions exist to remedy these complications: tuning processing parameters for a particular AM technology to print conventional alloys, and/or develop novel alloys specifically for AM. The majority of research into AM has sought the former solution, overlooking the fact that the majority of engineering alloys were designed for manufacturing via processing routes other than AM. To realize the latter solution of designing alloys for AM-amenability, criteria for printability are needed to screen for intrinsically printable alloys. In this work we demonstrate a CALPHAD-based indicator, the ratio of the characteristic solidification time and spreading time, $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , to screen for alloys of arbitrary composition, that are intrinsically resistant to balling, in a HTP manner. By visualizing the composition-dependence of the indicator in three exemplary ternary alloy systems, we have demonstrated its applicability to alloy design for AM. Furthermore, with an AM database, we demonstrated the ability of the proposed metric to predict if a proposed AM design will exhibit balling. A calibrated probabilistic classifier trained on $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , LED, and dwell time yielded log-loss and Brierloss scores of 0.235 and 0.070, indicating these features are able to account for most of the conditions that lead to balling in an AM print. As the cost of prototyping novel metallic AM prints is prohibitively expensive, printability criteria, such as $\tau _ { s o l i d } / \tau _ { s p r e a d }$ , will aid researchers in searching vast composition spaces for intrinsically printable alloys.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-1
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
N. Jeyaprakash1  · Che‑Hua Yang1 $\cdot$ G. Prabu2  · R. Clinktan3

Received: 14 December 2021 / Accepted: 28 February 2022 / Published online: 31 May 2022

summary: Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel‑625 Superalloy Produced by Selective Laser Melting

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-2
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: This research discusses the comparative investigation of the Inconel-625 superalloy manufactured by Selective Laser Melting (SLM) process and conventional process. The fabricated component was investigated to reveal the phase transformations, microstructural features and nano-hardness. Further, wear test was conducted on specimens manufactured by both the methods as above, to study the tribological properties. XRD analysis showed that the SLM specimen has more intensity at (111) difraction peak than the other two specimens and that the solid solution of $\gamma$ -(Ni, Cr, Fe) (FCC) phases grew at (111), (2 0 0) and (220) planes. The Inconel-625 powder had lattice parameters $0 . 3 5 9 2 { \mathrm { ~ n m } }$ , $0 . 3 1 1 6 \ \mathrm { n m }$ and $0 . 3 0 1 2 { \mathrm { n m } }$ , whereas the SLM specimen possessed the lattice parameters $0 . 3 5 9 9 { \mathrm { n m } }$ , $0 . 3 1 2 1 \mathrm { n m }$ and $0 . 3 0 1 2 \mathrm { n m }$ which were higher than the other two specimens. The microstructure analysis confrmed the presence of consistent and homogeneously equiaxed cell in the conventional alloy, whereas the SLM specimen possessed heterogeneous columnar structure. Along with the columnar cell, some equiaxed and cellular cell were also formed in the SLM specimen due to remelting of the overlapped region. Moreover, the formation of equiaxed cell in XY, YZ and ZX plane directions of the conventional alloy specimen and columnar cell in the SLM specimen was confrmed through Electron backscatter difraction (EBSD) analysis. The SLM-produced specimen exhibited higher nano-hardness due to the formation of angular columnar cell, fne hard phases, efective bonding strength and defect-free surface. Abrasive wear mechanism played an important role in both the samples. The wear rate of the conventional Inconel-625 alloy specimen was around $4 . 5 8 \times 1 0 ^ { - 3 } \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m }$ while it was $1 .

fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:

Thus, the SLM technique is a promising and predominant technique to develop nickel-based superalloys for frictional applications.

Keywords Nickel superalloy $\cdot$ Selective laser melting $\cdot$ Microstructure $\cdot$ EBSD $\cdot$ Nano-indentation $\cdot$ Wear mechanism

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-4
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Additive manufacturing (AM) is an advanced solid free form (SFF) technique and is highly utilized by many industries to develop fully functional metal components with complex geometry and high strength. The required 3D (3-Dimensional) model gets scanned and sliced by 2D (2-Dimensional) stacks into several layers, then the actual part is layered and consolidated by starting materials in either powder and wire form [1]. Adopting the AM process can reduce the processing time and it becomes easier to fabricate the near-net shape products. One such advanced technique in Direct Metal Laser Fabrication (DMLF), known as the Selective Laser Melting (SLM) process, fuses the powders in a particular area from a powder bed. The conventional methods are subtractive, but the material addition process has a unique advantage of rapid manufacturing along with economical material usage [2]. SLM is a new methodology in processing additive ways that is signifcantly faster in layer-by-layer fabrication of high strength and geometrically complex hard-to-machine metal parts [3]. Laser energy is used to fuse the powder particles in the powder bed system that create the required solid component. The build orientation is directed in the z-axis and a new layer is formed over the previously solidifed layer; this process continues until the component is fnished [4]. Researchers are continuously putting hard efort in fnding the superior bulk densifed materials with good mechanical properties and this can bring out the potential of SLM in manufacturing diferent metal parts [5, 6].

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-5
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Nickel-based superalloys are extensively used in various industrial engineering applications. The ever-increasing demand for superalloys, and particularly Inconel-based ${ \mathrm { N i } } { \mathrm { - C r } }$ for its preferential characteristics of high yield strength, tensile strength and creep resistance properties at high-temperature corrosion, is attractive in many felds such as aerospace, marine and oil industries. However, due to the high strength and hardness of Inconel-625 superalloy is being a challenging task using traditional methods [7]. Moreover, the nickel-based Inconel-625 alloy has the capability to withstand aggressive environments due to the solid solution strengthening of Mo and Nb elements [8, 9]. However, the nickel-based Inconel-625 superalloy is applied to various moving components typically subjected to several critical situations such as thermal stresses, fatigue loading and corrosion, and therefore experience higher mechanical energy losses due to wear and friction [10]. Hence, the control of wear and friction by the Inconel-625 superalloy is needed to extend the service life of moving mechanical components.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-6
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Balbaa et  al. [11] studied the surface integrity of the SLM-produced Inconel-625 superalloy and concluded that dense parts can be formed with lesser surface roughness. Javidrad and Salemi [12] investigated the elastic constants of additively produced Inconel-625 superalloy through the ultrasonic technique. The proposed ultrasonic technique resulted in a good correlation in the determination of elastic constants of additively produced Inconel-625 superalloy. Inaekyan et al. [13] studied the microstructure, grain orientation and stress–strain behaviour of SLM-made Inconel-625 superalloy. Alena et al. [14] examined the tensile property, fracture mechanism and stress–strain behaviour of SLMmade Inconel-625 superalloy in a high-temperature environment. Zhang et al. [15] studied the infuence of nano- $\cdot \mathrm { T i B } _ { 2 }$ with Inconel-625 alloy which is produced through laser aided additive manufacturing. The result showed that the reinforced nano- $\mathrm { T i B } _ { 2 }$ Inconel-625 improved the mechanical and tribological properties. From the above literature, it can be seen that many works have been carried out on the mechanical properties of the SLM-produced Inconel-625 superalloy. However, to the best of the authors' knowledge, no literature has been found on a comparison of the tribological study between the conventional Inconel-625 and SLM produced Inconel-625 superalloy. This study used the SLM process to fabricate Inconel-625 superalloy and compared its properties (phase evolution, microstructural features, nanohardness) with the conventionally produced Inconel-625 superalloy. Further, the tribological behaviour of the SLMproduced Inconel-625 and conventional Inconel-625 superalloy were studied, along with plausible wear mechanisms.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-7
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The commercially available gas atomized Inconel-625 powder was purchased from M/s. Circle metal powder company, Taiwan and was used to fabricate the specimen through the SLM process. To characterize the morphology and size of the powder particle, the Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) examination was performed using Sigma Gemini Column, Carl Zeiss, USA. The FESEM picture of Inconel-625 powder is shown in Fig. 1, in which the spherical shape of Inconel-625 particles is observed. Meanwhile, the amorphous surface is observed on fne powders and the overall particle size distribution gathered a particle diameter of minimum $1 5 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and maximum $5 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ , with an average particle size of $2 7 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . The size of the powder particles was measured by using the Image J software through the mean linear intercept method. Table 1 shows the chemical composition of the Inconel-625 powder, which was used to perform the SLM process.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-8
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The SLM system consists of a high-power fber laser, computerized numerically controlled XYZ plane platform and nitrogen-based inert atmosphere. The Yb: YAG disk laser (SLM Solution, M280, Germany) with a wavelength of $1 0 6 0 \mathrm { n m }$ was used in a continuous mode. Figure 2 represents the schematic view of the SLM process. The laser power (W) was varied with constant laser scan speed $\mathrm { ( m m / s ) }$ and spot size of the laser beam (micron) to obtain the optimum process parameter in order to produce a defect-free SLM specimen. The input data of the component model was separated into 759 layers where the thickness of each layer was $0 . 0 3 \mathrm { m m }$ and the build orientation movement was along the Z-Axis. The SLM printing base plate temperature was maintained at $2 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ during the working atmosphere. Table 2 shows the SLM process parameters used in the present study. For comparison purposes, commercially available conventionally produced Inconel-625 superalloy (Conventional Inconel-625 specimen) was purchased from M/s Gredmann company, Taiwan. Further, a small cuboid size of the sample was cut from the conventional Inconel-625 specimen and SLM produced the specimens through wire electrical discharge machining (WEDM). In the cuboid sample (X Y Z Plane), each axis was cut $2 0 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in length to examine the X-ray difraction (XRD) (D/MAX/2200/PC Ultima IV, Regaku, Japan) phase and microscopic analysis was performed. The testing samples were cut along the XY plane by using the wire EDM process and etched by Si grit sheets from 300 to 3000 GSM followed by double disc polishing with diamond paste. The chromic acid etchant was used to examine the surface morphology over the polished surface by Electron backscatter difraction (EBSD) measurements (Oxford Instruments NanoAnalysis, USA).

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-9
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
A Nano-indentation test (TI980 Hysitron, Bruker Nano indenters, USA) was conducted over the cross-sectional area of the conventional Inconel-625 specimen and SLM-produced specimen to fnd the strength in terms of hardness. The diamond tip intended area mark and crack nucleation were captured using optical microscopy.

The tribological properties of the conventional Inconel-625 specimen and SLM processed sample were examined through a dry sliding pin-on-disc wear tester machine (TR-20LE-PHM 400-CHM 500, Ducom Instruments, India). The hardened stainless steel was used as a counterpart with the dimensions of $1 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { m m } }$ diameter and $6 \mathrm { m m }$ thickness to slide the pin material. The wear testing input process parameters were applied with load $5 0 \mathrm { N }$ , sliding velocity $1 . 2 ~ \mathrm { m / s }$ , with a constant sliding distance of $2 8 0 0 \mathrm { m }$ . After completing each trial, the specimen was weighed to calculate the mass loss before and after the test. The output responses calculated were wear rate $( \mathrm { m m } ^ { 3 } / \mathrm { m } )$ and coefcient of friction (CoF). Meanwhile, from the wear test of Inconel-625 for specifc parameters, the importance of estimating the involvement of diferent wear mechanisms through worn-out surfaces was studied. In addition to that, the worn-out roughness average was measured using a white-light interferometer.

SLM specimen had more intensity at (111) difraction peak compared with the other two samples, which is consistent with the result obtained in reference [15]. It was revealed that the presence of solid solution $\gamma$ -(Ni, Cr, Fe) (FCC) phases grown at the (111), (2 0 0) and (220) planes. name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-12
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The calculated lattice parameters of high-intensity peaks are listed in Table  3. The Inconel-625 powder had lattice parameters of $0 . 3 5 9 2 { \mathrm { ~ n m } }$ , $0 . 3 1 1 6 \ \mathrm { n m }$ and $0 . 3 0 1 2 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ , whereas the SLM specimen possessed the lattice parameters of $0 . 3 5 9 9 { \mathrm { n m } }$ , $0 . 3 1 2 1 \mathrm { n m }$ and $0 . 3 0 1 2 \mathrm { n m }$ which were higher than the other two specimens. During the solidifcation of SLM specimen at steepest temperature gradients generated more heterogeneous nucleation of $\gamma$ nuclei align themselves results in accumulated fne structure morphology which resulted in an increase of lattice parameter [16]. Based on the XRD analysis, it was found that the $\gamma$ -matrix contained major elements of $\mathrm { C r }$ and Ni. From the Ni–Cr–Fe ternary alloy phase diagram, it was found that the major portion of the SLM specimen had a $\gamma$ -phase matrix that contained Ni, Cr and Fe elements [17]. The diference in the attribute of the SLM specimen compared to conventional alloy had occurred owing to the variation in solidifcation of multielement solid-solution of a $\gamma$ -Ni phase of the SLM specimen.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-13
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: Phases related to Nb and Mo elements are not observed in this present XRD diagram (Fig. 3a) due to the small content of Nb and Mo elements. Moreover, there was no precipitation of MC carbide intermetallic phases in the SLM specimen. However, during the SLM process, a small content of Nb formed as $\mathrm { N i } _ { 3 } \mathrm { N b }$ orthorhombic phase and MC carbide elements based on the presence of Nb and Mo in EDS analysis on the SLM specimen (Fig. 6g and Table 4), which is analysed in Sect. 3.2. Moreover, the presence of a small amount of Nb and Mo in the $\gamma$ -matrix led to an increase in the lattice distortion as the lattice constant reached a maximum. The reason behind the growth of these $\mathrm { N i } _ { 3 } \mathrm { N b }$ , Mo and MC carbide phases between crystals was that the Ni and $\mathrm { C r }$ elements in the Inconel-625 powder started to solidify from liquid to $\gamma$ phases at a beginning stage. This process continued until all high-temperature melting point elements solidifed. The melting points of Nb, C and Mo are $2 4 7 7 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , $3 3 5 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ and $2 6 2 3 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ , respectively. However, the alloy's melting point of Nb, C and Mo are reduced due to the formation of the eutectic composition as the eutectic reaction of liquid to $\gamma$ phases and MC carbide were occurred by consuming C elements. This reaction continued and enriched the inter-crystal region. However, the presence of these phases was very less as the cooling rate of solidifed region in the SLM process was around $1 0 5 ~ \mathrm { K / s }$ which was extremely high compared to the conventional process [18]. As a result, the reconstruction velocity of Nb, C and Mo atoms was higher than the difusion velocity at the solid–liquid intersection region.

Consequently, Nb, C and Mo elements were entrapped at the solid–liquid intersection which led to the formation of solution trapping at the interphase region. Hence, Mo, C and Nb-based intermetallic phases were hardly formed in the SLM specimen. In addition to that, other phases had not been found in the XRD patterns of the SLM specimen due to the small content and smaller size of the precipitation. content:
The XRD peak of the SLM specimen at 44.32 was shifted toward the direction of the high-angle side compared to (111) plane Inconel-625 powder, which can be clearly viewed from the magnifed view in Fig. 3b. Among the specimens, the SLM specimen was shifted to 45.32 angle, whereas the conventional specimen shifted to 45.45 from the Inconel-625 powder. From this data, it was found that the SLM specimen had a positive angle deviation from the powder and a negative angle deviation from the conventional alloy due to change in crystal lattice [10]. Moreover, the position of XRD peak is also sensitive to residual stress of materials [19]. It has been well known that the SLM-processed samples usually have excessive residual stress due to ultrafast heating and cooling rates during the process, which could have an efect on peak position of the XRD data [20]. After analysing the XRD (Fig. 3) and EDS results on SLM specimen (Fig. 6g and Table 4), it was found that the formation of the $\gamma { \mathrm { - N i } }$ phase followed the sequence below to solidify from the molten pool to the fnal stage of formation of $\gamma$ -(Ni, Cr, Fe) phase [21].

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-17
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: 200 and $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ at the laser beam spot size of $1 0 0 \mu \mathrm { m }$ and scanning speed of $9 2 5 ~ \mathrm { { m m } / \mathrm { { s } } }$ for obtaining a defect-free surface. The FESEM image of the SLM Inconel-625 specimen at $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ laser powder is shown in Fig. 4. The SLM specimen had uneven melted particles that were found at the interfaces of the grain boundaries (Fig. 4a). Moreover, discontinuous grain boundaries, cracks and shrinkage cavities were observed on the SLM processed surface (Fig. 4b). Columnar cells with long cracked zones were found in most of the locations. These defects reduced the densifcation of the SLM specimen. Based on this analysis, it was found that the molten pool had surface tension during the melting of the diferent volumes of the Inconel-625 particles (Fig. 1). During this melting process, some part of the kinetic energy of the laser beam was transferred as the surface energy of the powder particles. Moreover, it produced small droplets of Inconel-625 metal as a result of the combined efect of gravity and surface tension. Some of these droplets were splashed and settled at the grain boundary and fnally solidifed as particles segregation. These segregations are observed in Fig. 4a which are evidences for the above-specifed claim.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-18
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: The liquid formation in the SLM system was entirely dependent on the generation of temperature. The high viscosity of the Inconel-625 at $2 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ impeded the spreading out of the liquid smoothly that led to the formation of grain boundary segregation (Fig. 4b) and resulted in the reduction of the relative density. Moreover, the instability of the formation of liquid tended to reduce the surface energy, which caused the breaking up of the liquid. Subsequently, a discontinuous boundary region occurred. Similarly, the shrinkage cavity and crack formed during the SLM process were also responsible for the growth of undesirable surface morphology. These defects were diminished by increasing the fuidity of Inconel-625 molten powder before solidifcation by increasing the laser power to $3 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ .

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-19
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content: FESEM image of commercially purchased conventionally produced Inconel-625 specimen is shown in Fig. 5a. A consistent uniform cells were observed and the cell size were in the range of $1 0 { - } 2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ . The resultant FESEM images at $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { W }$ laser energy density are shown in Fig. 5b–f. Melt pool and grains are denoted in the FESEM images in Fig. 5b and c, respectively. Particle segregation due to balling efects was not observed in this surface due to the remelting action on the overlap regions. Solute segregations were not observed at boundaries. Moreover, during the SLM process, the cells are grown and align themselves in the direction of the steepest temperature gradients. Consequently, a defectfree surface was formed on the SLM specimen at 300 W. The SLM specimen has a smooth surface that has fully melted particles along the laser track region and the intersection areas of the neighboring boundaries. Moreover, cracks and boundary segregation were not noted in the SLM specimen at $3 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ specimen compared to the $\operatorname { S L M } 2 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ specimen. Figure 5d clearly distinguishes the orientation of columnar cell due to its growth at specifc directions during the solidifcation process within the molten pool. The columnar cell became uniformly arranged at the $3 0 0 \mathrm { W }$ laser power even though it was arranged in a diferent direction. The melting track overlapped with the adjacent track and generated a fully dense structure. The Inconel-625 powder melted rapidly before the pool front and solidifed as fast as the laser beam moves away. Moreover, during this SLM process, dissipation of heat from the molten pool to the zones beside, bottom layer and the cooling rate afected the shape, orientation and size of cells in the 3D printed region [22, 23]. Horizontal and vertical direction columnar crystals were observed in the 3D printed region.

name: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by-part-20
fileName: 2022 - Metals and Materials Int. - Jeyaprakash et al. - Microstructure and Tribological Behaviour of Inconel-625 Superalloy Produced by.md
content:
The direction of the movement of the molten pool controls the orientation of the structure of the columnar dendrite (Fig. 5d). The horizontal direction columnar cell was formed due to heat received from the remelted zone and $5 0 \%$ of overlap with the adjacent printing tracks. Moreover, the bottom layer acted as a heat sink region [24, 25], which resulted in the generation of columnar cell that was perpendicular to the bottom layer. Diferent orientation of columnar cell was formed due to remelting of the overlap region of the former track as well as the next track. As a result, the originally formed columnar cell were broken and formed various directions of columnar cell (Fig. 5d). Moreover, a long period of heat dissipation to the bottom layers and adjusting region led to shortening of the length of the columnar cell. Moreover, along with this columnar cell, some cellular cell is observed in Fig. 5d due to the transfer of heat energy by convection. The size of the cellular cells changed from 0.5 to $1 \mu \mathrm { m }$ . Table 4 EDS analysis results of Conventional alloy specimen and SLM specimens
